==Welcome==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Tjj!
{| cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="margin:0em 0em 1em 0em; width:100%" | style="width:45%; vertical-align:top; border:1px solid #fad67d; background-color:#faf6ed;" |
[[Image:Crystal Clear app korganizer.png|20px]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for freely-licensed collaboratively-developed [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].'''
You don't need technical skills in order to contribute here. '''[[WB:BOLD|Be bold]]''' contributing here and ''[[WB:AGF|assume good faith]]'' for the intentions of others. Remember, this is a ''[[w:wiki|wiki]]'', so you're allowed to change just about anything & it is really easy. Come say [[WB:HELP|hello]] to everyone!
[[Image:Icon apps query.svg|20px]] '''Getting help'''
* You can always get help from the community in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]] or in our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * If something you wrote was tagged with {{tlx|query}}, and you think this was done in error, just remove it & explain why on the talk page. * If your upload was tagged with {{tlx|nld}}, {{tlx|bfu}}, or {{tlx|nfur}}, please read the template message as it explains the violation of [[WB:MEDIA|our media policy]]. Please be sure to provide the required {{tlx|information}}: a [[WB:ICT|license tag]] & source are always required; fair use images require a {{tlx|fair use rationale}}. | style="padding:0em 0.5em 0em 0.5em;" | | style="width:55%; vertical-align:top; border:1px solid #abd5f5; background-color:#f1f5fc;" |
[[Image:Transmission icon.png|20px]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please [[:w:Wikipedia:Sign your posts on talk pages|sign your name]] on discussion pages by typing ~~~~ * If you're coming here from Wikipedia, you should read [[WB:WFW|our primer for Wikipedians]] to get up-to-speed quickly. * '''Please make sure you follow our [[WB:NP|naming policy]]''' - modules should be named like Book Title/Chapter Title. * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
[[Image:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (only become available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To get a page deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason for requesting deletion''}} to the top of the page. * If something you wrote was deleted, please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:VFD|VFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:VFU]].
|- |align=right colspan=3|(P.S. Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?) |} ==Please use the [[Sandbox]]== Your test worked and has been removed. Please use the [[Sandbox]] for any future tests, and welcome to Wikibooks! --[[User:Jomegat|Jomegat]] ([[User talk:Jomegat|talk]]) 12:25, 16 September 2008 (UTC) ==[[:BISU Network Class]]== {{mbox|type=notice|msg= [[:BISU Network Class|This page]] appears to have been created in error (due to a test, or some kind of [[Help:Editing|misplaced edit]]). It might be a [[Help:Stub|stub]], if so, please use [[Talk:BISU Network Class|the discussion page]] as to explain what this page is about. If it evolves into a [[WB:WIW|legitimate Wikibooks module]], you may remove the tag. If not fixed, explained, or improved, it will automatically be considered a candidate for [[Wikibooks:Deletion policy#Speedy deletions|speedy deletion]] in 7 days.  '''— [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 17:30, 18 September 2008 (UTC) }}

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Brazil|Brazilian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Crab | Crab recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Seafood | Seafood recipes]]
==Ingredients==
*2 pounds crabmeat, drained if using canned *3 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] *4 tomatoes, peeled, seeded and chopped *1 tablespoon palm oil *3/4 cup of [[Cookbook:Coconut Milk|coconut milk]] *2 tablespoons fresh chopped parsley *2 tablespoons fresh chopped green onions *4 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *Bread crumbs *grated [[Cookbook:Parmesan Cheese|Parmesan cheese]] *Salt and pepper to taste *crab or scallop shells
==Procedure==
#Heat olive oil and saute onions until soft. #Stir in crabmeat for 3-5 minutes. Add tomatoes and simmer for 5-8 minutes. #Add coconut milk, salt, pepper and palm oil, cooking for 3-5 minutes. #Remove from heat, add flour at small quantities, stirring continually. Bring the pan back to heat, cooking until get a cream. Stir in parsley and green onions. Remove from heat. #Fill the shells with this mixture, top with bread crumbs mixed with Parmesan cheese. #Bake for 15-20 minutes or until lightly brown.
[[Category:Brazilian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Seafood recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Crab recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Appetizer recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

__NOTOC__ __NOEDITSECTION__ [[Image:Couple lying on grass.jpg|thumb|“Learning a language requires time, hard work, and dedication on the part of the learner” {{ref|Ferraro}}|400px]] [[Image:Palenque_ruins_web.jpg|thumb|View of Palenque, a Maya ruin in Chiapas, Mexico|400px]] [[Image:Bilbao.Guggenheim10.jpg|thumb|View of the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain|400px]] == Contents ==
 
*[[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod lessons|'''SPANISHPOD LESSONS''']] *:Lessons based on [http://spanishpod.com SpanishPod] newbie lessons for beginners without knowledge of Spanish; teaching language is English; no prerequisites.
<!-- *Aesop's Fables [[Image:00%.svg]] *:For beginners with some knowledge of Spanish. --> *[[Spanish by Choice/Novelas Cortas|'''SHORT STORIES BY ALARCÓN''']] *:Spanish short stories from the book “Novelas Cortas” by Pedro Antonio de Alarcón read by Karen Savage. For intermediate learners.
== Introduction == ===What is this wikibook?=== This wikibook is quite different from a normal Spanish course. In fact, it is more like a collection of booklets, which accompany audio courses and audio books. As it is an electronic wikibook, it combines audio files with transcripts, vocabulary lists, interactive exercises, images, forums, etc.
===How to read this wikibook=== As suggested by its title, the structure of this wikibook emphasizes ''choice''; thus, there really isn't a single way of reading it but you can ''choose'' how to explore the material offered in this wikibook. Here are some common user types: * ''Hoppers'' jump from one lesson to another using the tables of contents, the index of dialogue lines, links between related lessons, or just random browsing. If they encounter a lesson they already know, they often listen to it again to see what they remember. * ''Old-school learners'' listen to the lessons in the order they are indexed in the tables of contents. They also have a system to listen to the lessons again after certain time intervals (typically after some days, after some weeks, and after some months). * ''Commuters'' download audio lessons to their audio players or burn them on CDs to listen to them multiple times on their daily commute. In the evening they read through the corresponding pages of this wikibook and choose the next lessons. * ''Fans'' of particular podcasts don't really care about the order in which they enjoy their favourite shows. They also tend to listen to particular lessons over and over again just for the fun of it.
===How to use this wikibook=== A few additional technical warnings and tips: *The built-in audio player of Firefox is not recommended for playing the audio files because it tends to skip the last second of each file. The VLC media player is also not recommended because it tends to skip the first second of each file. *For printing use the links to printable versions and PDF versions on the '''top, right'''. Printing with the links on the '''left''' ("Create a book", "Download as PDF", and "Printable version") generates inferior results. *Note that all printable pages include a copy of the complete GNU free documentation license. *To organize your personal sets of lessons, use the "Create a book" link on the left. *The SpanishPod newbie lessons are also available as a '''podcast''': see the [http://www.martin-kraus.org/feeds/spanishbychoice.rss RSS file] and the [http://itunes.apple.com/WebObjects/MZStore.woa/wa/viewPodcast?id=300660557 iTunes page].
===How to contribute to this wikibook=== Please correct any typos and errors that you find. If you want to include a link or image: be bold and just do it! Apart from the SpanishPod newbie lessons licensed under a creative commons license and the LibriVox recording of Novelas Cortas, further suitable podcasts and audio material should be included in this wikibook. Unfortunately, most podcasts are not published under a suitable license for Wikimedia Commons and/or make (fair) use of copyrighted material, which is not acceptable for Wikimedia Commons. On the other hand, the public domain [http://librivox.org/newcatalog/search_advanced.php?title=&author=&cat=&genre=&status=all&type=&language=Spanish&date=&reader=&bc=&mc=&action=Search Spanish audiobooks at librivox.org] and the articles in the [http://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikiproyecto:Wikipedia_grabada Spanish version of spoken Wikipedia] should be suitable. Please discuss any suggestions or ideas on the discussion page or contact [[User:Martin Kraus|Martin]].
==References== # {{note|Ferraro}} Gary P. Ferraro, "The Cultural Dimension of International Business," ISBN 0131927671, 9780131927674, Prentice Hall, 2005, page 73.
== See also == * [[w:en:Spanish grammar|Wikipedia article on "Spanish Grammar"]] * [[w:en:Spanish language|Wikipedia article on "Spanish Language"]] * [[Wikijunior:Languages/Spanish]] * [[Spanish|Wikibook "Spanish"]] * [[The Wrong Way To Learn Spanish|Wikibook "The Wrong Way To Learn Spanish"]]

__NOTOC__ {| style="float: right; width: 250px;" |- | {{User language|de|N}} |- | {{User language|en|3}} |- | {{User language|es|1}} |- | {{User print version}} |- | {{User audiobooks}} |} {{Print version of module|User:Martin Kraus/Print version||this page}} ===User Accounts=== * English Wikipedia: [[w:en:User:Martin_Kraus]] * German Wikipedia: [[w:de:User:Martin_Kraus]] * German Wikibooks: [[:de:User:Martin_Kraus]] * Wikimedia Commons: [[commons:User:Martin_Kraus]] ===Activities=== ====[[Canvas 2D Web Apps]]==== I've been thinking about how to teach programming web apps for some years. What is the best technology? What are the best tools? What is the best literature? I'm still not sure; thus, I'm writing a wikibook to try one approach. So far, I'm quite happy with the results: the book uses JavaScript and the HTML Canvas 2D Context and shows how to use this for a combination of automata-based programming and reactive programming. The resulting web apps can be used in desktop and mobile web browsers as well as in iBooks. ====[[Cg Programming]]==== After having spent quite a bit of time on the GLSL wikibook, I adapted it to Cg (and slightly extended it); mainly in order to provide students with more suitable learning material. ====[[GLSL Programming]]==== I've written a wikibook on GLSL (OpenGL Shading Language) programming to support a course that I've been teaching in October 2011. One of the basic ideas is to introduce learners to the way GLSL is used in context, in particular in Unity, Blender, and OpenGL+GLUT. This could be extended to WebGL, Android, and iOS. Notable feature: section numbers in the PDF version. ====[[German]]==== I've been working a bit on reorganizing [[German]], making the Level II levels accessible again and trying to integrate the exercises in the Level I lessons. There is still a lot of work to do on this book but I'm not really finding the time or motivation to do it. ====[[Spanish by Choice]]==== I'm the main author of [[Spanish by Choice]], a collection of wikibooklets for everyone who wants to learn Spanish. With this wikibook I've also been trying to better understand the possibilities of wikibooks in general. There could be a lot of stuff done with the Novelas Cortas because there are excellent open-source audio recordings available but I'm not quite sure how to do it with reasonable effort. {{SbcTasks}} ===My Sandbox===

revision.text: {{Template:MCG}} == Prepositions == === General === {| style="background:gainsboro" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="5" |- | style="background:silver" | 跟 || style="background:lightgrey" | gēn || with |} {| cellpadding="3" cellspacing="5" |- || 我想跟你一起吃晚饭 ◦ || wŏ xiăng gēn nĭ yìqĭ chī wǎnfàn. || I would like to have dinner with you. |- || 儿子跟我们在这儿 ◦ || érzĭ gēn wŏmen zài zhè'er. || The son is here with us. |} === Location === {| style="background:gainsboro" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="5" |- | style="background:silver" | 在|| style="background:lightgrey" | zài || (located) at, in |} {| cellpadding="3" cellspacing="5" |- || 在饭店 || zài fàn diàn || at the restaurant |- || 我的朋友在我那儿 ◦ || wŏ de péngyou zài wŏ nà'r. || My friend is at my place. |- || 我的太太在香港 ◦ || wŏ de tài tài zài Xiānggǎng. || My wife is in Hong Kong. |- || 我们住在美国 ◦ || wŏmen zhù zài měiguó. || We live in America. |- || 学院路在哪儿 ?|| Xuéyuàn lù zài nă'r? || Where is College Road located? |- || 是不是在这儿 ? || shì bù shì zài zhè'r?|| Is it located here? |- || 我不想在那儿吃 ◦ || wŏ bù xiăng zài nà'r chī. || I would not like to eat over there. |- || 在那儿不太贵 ◦ || zài nà'r bù tài guì. || Over there it's not too expensive. |- || 她跟你的先生在一起 ◦ || tā gēn nĭ de xiānshēng zài yìqĭ. || She is with your husband (literally: She with your husband are located together). |} [[Category:Mandarin Chinese Grammar for Pimsleur Students|Prepositions]]

revision.text:
{{Data Management in Bioinformatics/ChapNav}} = Theory of Relations = == Introduction to Biological Databases == Organisms are categorized as [[w:Prokaryotes|Prokaryotes]] and [[w:Eukaryotes|Eukaryotes]]. The central dogma of molecular biology lays down that DNA is transcribed to mRNA, which is then translated to proteins. The proteins carry out life functions in the cell. The genetic material in a cell consists of several strands of DNA double helix formed into a super coiled structure. The DNA molecule consists of sugar-phosphate backbone on which nucleotides form base pairs. The 4 bases are denoted by the letters A,C,T and G. T pairs with A and C pairs with G in the DNA double helix. == A few sample Biological Databases == * Genomes ** GenBank: a collection of all publicly available DNA sequences maintained by NIH.[http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Genbank] * Protein ** PDB: A protein database [http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/home/home.do] * Function & Annotation * Interaction Databases - Protein-protein Interaction ** BIND: Biomolecular Interaction Network Database [http://bond.unleashedinformatics.com/] * Pathways ** Chemical Reaction Pathways: KEGG Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes ** Signal Transduction (i.e. response to external signals): STKE Signal Transduction Knowledge Environment [http://stke.sciencemag.org/] * Text ** PubMed:Collection of biology research articles. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed] * Organism Specific database ** Yeast [http://www.yeastgenome.org/] ** Pathogen: [http://patric.vbi.vt.edu/ PATRIC] This is hosted at [http://www.vbi.vt.edu/ VBI]. The Jan Issue of [http://nar.oxfordjournals.org Nucleic Acids Research] journal is a catalog of biological databases. == Course content == * '''Data Models''' ** Relational ** Object Oriented ** Hierarchical ** Semi-structured ** Unstructured (e.g. Text) * '''Model of Querying''': SQL * '''Information Integration''' * '''Data Mining''' == The Relational Model == ;Set: A collection of objects : Let A and B be two sets, A = \{a, b, c\} and B = \{1, 2, 4\} ;Cartesian Product: of A,B is the set consisting all possible pairs taking one object from set A and the other from set B. : {{math|A × B {{=}} {(a,1),(a,2),(a,4),(b,1),(b,2),(b,4),(c,1),(c,2),(c,4)}}} ;Relation: is a subset of the Cartesian product. === An example of a relation === {| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- !Gene ID|| Name|| Annotation || Expt ID || Expt. Desc. || Expression Level |- |g2347|| p53|| Tumor Suppressor || e0 || Heat Shock || +2 |- |g2347|| p53|| Tumor Suppressor || e1 || Cold Shock || -1 |- |g2347|| p53|| Tumor Suppressor || e2 || Desiccation || 0 |- |...|| ...|| ... || ... || ... || ... |} The above is an example of an Un-Normalized Relation. And has the following problems: * '''Redundancy''': The gene information is repeated for different experiments and potentially experiment information can be common to several genes * '''Update Anomaly''': If the annotation of a gene needs to be updated, several rows of the table need update. * '''Deletion Anomaly''': Deleting a gene can result in loss of information about an experiment. == Designing Tables == === Entity-Relationship Diagrams === [[Image:BulbgraphOnOff.gif]] \rightarrow E/R Diagram \rightarrow Relations/Tables The above figure suggests how the E/R model is used in database design. We start with ideas about the information we want to model and render them in the E/R model. The abstract E/R design is then converted to a schema in the data-specification language of some DBMS. Most commonly, this DBMS uses the relational model. If so, then by a fairly mechanical process, the abstract design is converted to a concrete, relational design, called a "relational database schema". {| border="0" cellpadding="5" |- !Entity (Nouns)|| Relation (Verbs) |- |Gene|| Subjected To |- |Experiment|| |} ==== Reading a 2-way relationship ==== [[Image:2-way-relation.svg|center|400px]] Many-to-many relation (no arrows) # One A '''can''' be related to many B's e.g one '''gene''' can be '''subjected to''' many '''experiments''' # One B '''can''' be related to many A's e.g. one '''experiment''' can '''subject''' many '''genes''' [[Image:2-way-relation-with-arrow.png|center|400px]] One-to-one (arrows in both sides) # One A '''can''' be related '''at most''' one B e.g. one '''DNA molecule''' can be '''transcribed''' to at most one '''RNA primary transcript''' # One B '''can''' be related '''at most''' one A e.g. one '''RNA primary transcript''' can be '''transcribed''' from at most one '''DNA molecule''' [[Image:2-way-many-to-one-relation.png|center|600px]] many-to-one (an arrow to the '''one''' side) # One A '''can''' be related to '''at most''' one B e.g. one '''codon''' can '''encode''' at most one '''amino acid''' # One B '''can''' be related to '''many''' A's e.g. one '''amino acid''' can be '''encoded''' by many '''codons''' ==== A 3-way relationship ==== [[Image:3-way-ERD.svg|center|400px]] S => Student, C => Course, I => Instructor # Any (S,C) pair '''can''' have many I's # Any (S,I) pair '''can''' have many C's # Any (C,I) pair '''can''' have many S's ==== Replacing a 3-way relationship ==== The following is another example of the 3-way relationship (ternary relationship) [[Image:cs5634-3-way-prescribe.png|center|250px]] The relationship can be replaced with a set of binary relationships as in the following: For instance, A = > Doctor, B => Patient, C => Drug, R => Prescribe {| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- !R|| A|| B|| C |- |r1|| a1|| b1|| c2 |- |r2|| a1|| b2|| c1 |- |r3|| a2|| b1|| c1 |- |r4|| a2|| b1|| c2 |- |} However, the diagram is not equivalent to the following diagram: [[Image:cs5634-2-way-prescribe-notequiv.png|center|220px]] The 2=way relations in the diagram are (A,B), (B,C), and (C,A). The three binary relations have different meaning with the given ternary relation. For example, association of a set of doctors with a certain pair of a patient and a drug cannot be modeled with the binary relationships. It is modeling decision whether a relation should be represented as a ternary relation or a set binary relations such as the above. ==== Boxing a 2-way relationship ==== Usually, boxing a thing means that the entity is important to have its own space rather than a concept to model relationships. When boxing a relation, the name of the entity often becomes the noun phrases from the verb in the relation name. For example, the ER model such as the following [[Image:cs5634-2-way-birth.png|center|300px]] An examples of tables for the model is: {| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- !Birth|| Mother|| Baby |- |b1|| Sue || Tom |- |b2|| Sue || Marry |- |b3|| Jane || Robert |- |} The following model also can be used to replace the original model. But it has different meaning with the previous model. An example of tables for the model is: {| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- !Birth|| Mother|| Baby |- |b1|| Sue || Tom |- |b1|| Sue || Marry |- |b2|| Jane || Robert |- |} Such a boxing of an relationship give more flexibility. === Attributes, Keys === The properties of a entity or a relation is called as attributes. The attributes are denoted as balloons attached to the entity or the relation. The attributes are also required to be in table as columns. Gene expression process can be divided into several steps and transcription process is one of the steps. mRNA is synthesized from DNA through the transcription process. Also, cDNA is synthesized from the mRNA through reverse transcription process. A microarray is a chip that a lot of DNA sequences are aligned on its surface. In DNA microarray experiment, the synthesized cDNA is poured on the chip and the cDNA binds to complementing DNA sequence on the chip by hybridization. The bound cDNA is measured to quantify the gene expression level in the experiment. As mentioned before, a relation also can have attributes. Here is an example of relations with attributes. [[Image:cs5634-2-way-takes-attr.png|center|250px]] An attribute or a set of attributes whose value is unique for each instance of entity is called a candidate key. There can be multiple candidate keys for an entity and the candidate key selected to identify the entity is called a (primary) key. The name of the key is underlined in ER digram. For example, ssn and sid is unique for all students so both are candidate keys. either ssn or sid can be selected as the primary key for entity type 'student'. === Creating tables from ERD === Converting an E/R design to a relational database schema is fairly mechanical and straightforward # Turn each entity set into a relation with the same set of attributes, and # Replace a relationship by a relation whose attributes are the keys for the connected entity sets For # many-many relation - the key for the relation representing relationship must be the union of keys from the participating entity sets # many-one relation - the key for the relation representing relationship must come from the many part # one-one relation - key for either of the participating entity set could be a key for the relation For example, [[Image:cs5634-2-way-takes-key.png|center|300px]] The key of 'takes' depend on the cardinality of the relation. The key for each cardinality of the relation is: #many to many relation -> a,c #one to many relation -> c #one to one relation -> a or c If 'takes' is an one to many cardinality relation, the tables generated from the model would be # Student(\underline{a}, b) # Courses(\underline{c}, d) # Takes(\underline{a}, \underline{c}) Here are examples of generated tables for 3-way relations. Tables for A,B, and C is omitted. [[Image:cs5634-3-way-ABC-key-noarrow.png|center|150px]] # R(\underline{a}, \underline{b},\underline{c}) [[Image:cs5634-3-way-ABC-key-onearrow.png|center|150px]] # R(\underline{a}, \underline{b}, c ) [[Image:cs5634-3-way-ABC-key-twoarrows.png|center|150px]] either one of the following two tables is possible. # R(\underline{a}, \underline{b}, c) # R(\underline{a}, b, \underline{c}) The following is an example for an unary relation. [[Image:cs5634-1-way-key.png|center|200px]] # A(\underline{a}) # R(\underline{a1}, \underline{a2}) Here is another example. [[Image:cs5634-2-way-takes-rel-key.png|center|350px]] # A(\underline{a}) # C(\underline{c}) # R(\underline{a}, \underline{c}, r) == Weak sets == There can be many counties with the same name in different states. For example, counties with the name of Montgomery are in Virginia, Texas, Maryland, so on. So the name of a county cannot be the key for the entity of counties. However, a key for counties can be acquired by combining the name of states and the name of the county. Such entities that do not have key in their attributes are called weak sets or weak entities. The keys of such entities can be acquired from attributes of certain related entities. The related entities are often called identifying entities. The relation from the weak set to its identifying entities are called identifying relations. [[Image:CS5634-counties-weak-set.png|center|400px]] The above ER diagram models shows a binary relation between States and Counties. The double bordered rectangle denotes the weak set and the identifying entity is States because combination of two characters for a state and the name of a county identify a county. The notation of double bordered relation in the diagram denotes the identifying relation too. The identifying entities can be found by searching the double bordered diamonds and see the arrow from the diamonds. [[Image:DMiB weak set.svg|center|400px]] ''Weak sets'' are entity sets that don't supply all of their own keys (see diagram) They rely on other entity sets to supply some or all of their keys. We encode this E/R diagram as: # A(\underline{a}, c) # B(\underline{a}, \underline{c}, d) # R(\underline{a}, \underline{c}) Notice that R does not have a written twice. We do not need to encode the weak relationship completely. It is implicit from the encoding of B. [[Image:DMiB weak set more.svg|center|600px]] We encode the entity sets of this next E/R diagram as: # A(\underline{a}, b) # B(\underline{a}, \underline{c}, \underline{e}, d) # C(\underline{e}) === Questions about weak sets === [[Image:DMiB weak set 2.svg|center|400px]] {{dynamic navigation |title = Is this E/R diagram valid? |bodystyle=text-align:left; margin:10px; |body = No, it is not valid. For any instance of B, there must only be one A, otherwise it would have multiple instances of the same kind of key. There should be an arrow pointing to A. }} [[Image:DMiB weak set 3.svg|center|400px]] {{dynamic navigation |title = Is this E/R diagram valid? |bodystyle=text-align:left; margin:10px; |body = No, it is not valid. This diagram means: # For every A, B, there is one C # For every A, C, there are many Bs # For every B, C, there is one A} This does not exclude the possibility of one B having many As. There is no unambiguous way to draw a weak set that draws keys from two other entity sets with an E/R diagram without having two separate relationships. }} === Causes of weak sets === [[Image:DMiB convert relation to entity set.svg|center|700px]] # Converting a relationship to an entity set (see diagram) # Hierarchy Notice in #1 that there are arrows pointing to all the original entity sets. We need these, because each relation entity may only have one A, B, and C. Hierarchy is an interesting situation, which leads us into inheritance. == Inheritance == In this section, we will discuss inheritance; what it is, why we use it, and how to use it. === What is inheritance? === ''Inheritance'' occurs when one thing (an entity set) is a subset of something else (some other entity set). One way to start examining if an entity set A inherits from another entity set B is to ask if "A IS A B".
Inheritance is when you can say `$A$ IS A $B$' with a straight face, and if you ever run for office no one will point out that you said it. ~Naren Ramakrishnan
''Are the following valid inheritance?'' # apple IS A fruit # apple IS A cow # g23 IS A gene #1 is correct, because an apple is a fruit. #2 is not correct, because an apple is not a cow. #3, however, is not correct because g23 is a specific gene, it does not quite demonstrate what we want to see in inheritance. A better way to test for inheritance is if you can say "$A$ IS A TYPE OF $B$". === Why do we use inheritance? === We use inheritance to give subsets of entity sets the attributes of its parent entity set, and let it extend that with extra information. When we say that "$A$ IS A $B$", we are already communicating a lot of information. For example, when we say that an "apple IS A fruit", even if we don't quite know what an "apple" is, we've communicated that an "apple" has seeds, is a part of a larger plant, and tastes better than a typical vegetable. [[Image:DMiB multiple inheritance.svg|center|500px]] Examine the diagram. A mammal is an animal, and so is a reptile. Both have an id, genus, weight, species, and safety level (whatever that means). Both mammals and reptiles inherit these attributes. It's important to note that in an inheritance relationship, the child entity set inherits the key of the parent entity set. In this example, the key for both mammals and reptiles is their animal id. The reason why we bother creating separate entity sets for mammals and reptiles is that we want to add attributes to each. Notice that mammals have a hair count and reptiles have an egg count. Instead of creating an entirely new entity set to explain this, we simply use inheritance to say that a mammal is an animal that has a hair count, and a reptile is an animal that has an egg count. Some animals have both a hair count, and an egg count. Let's call these animals ``weirdos''. We can see from the diagram, that we do not have to add any extra attributes to weirdos if we just use multiple inheritance and make a weirdo both a mammal and a reptile. Implicitly, a weirdo is also an animal and has all the attributes of an animal, including the key, id. In other words, inheritance is transitive. === How do we use inheritance? === We encode the entity sets in the diagram as: # Animals(\underline{id}, genus, species, weight, safetylevel) # Mammals(\underline{id}, hair count) # Reptiles(\underline{id}, egg count) We don't have to encode weirdos, they are implicit. Notice that while weak sets have different keys, inheriting sets don't have different keys. Notice also that inheriting sets get ''all'' of their parents' attributes, not just some of them. === Questions about inheritance === [[Image:DMiB circular relationship 1.svg|center|400px]] {{dynamic navigation |title = Could the diagram be valid? |bodystyle=text-align:left; margin:10px; |body = Yes, it could be valid, depending on the relationships. Consider the relationship between rural counties and states as "sells to". Also, notice that because we have single inheritance, we have to add an attribute to rural counties. }} [[Image:DMiB circular relationship 2.svg|center|400px]] {{dynamic navigation |title = Could the diagram in be valid? |bodystyle=text-align:left; margin:10px; |body = Yes, it could be valid. Consider the new relationship to also be "sells to". }} {{BookCat}}
{{softredirect|w:User:Ukexpat}}

{| width=90% cellpadding="2" style="float:center; border: 1px solid #333333; background: #f9fdff; margin: 1em auto;" |- |align="center" colspan="2" | '''Chapter Navigation''' |- |[[Data Management in Bioinformatics|Top]] | [[Data Management in Bioinformatics/ER Theory|E/R Theory]] - [[Data Management in Bioinformatics/Normalization|Normalization]] - [[Data Management in Bioinformatics/Data Querying|Data Querying]] - [[Integrating SQL and Programming Languages]] |}{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], typos fixed: frome → from, Funtional → Functional (2) using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Data Management in Bioinformatics/ChapNav}} = Functional Dependency (FD) = == Introduction of FD == {| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- !gene_id || name || annotation |- | ... || ... || ... |- | g23 || hsp39 || XX protein |- | g24 || hsp39 || XX protein |} Functional Dependency: X->Y if two tuples agree on X, then they agree on Y. e.g. "gene_id -> name" and "gid-> annotation" are FDs, but "name->gene_id" and "name->annotation" are NOT FDs. '''Relationship between key and FD:''' A set of attribute{A1, A2, ...At} is a key for relation R if (1) {A1, A2, ...At} functionally determines all other attributes; (2) when no proper subset of {A1, A2, ...At} functionally determin all other attributes, it is called superkey (or Candidate key?) '''rules of FDs:''' Observation: Correct: X->Y, A->B: XA->BY; X->AY: X->A, X->Y; X->Y, A->Y: XA->Y; Incorrect: XY->A: X->A, Y->A; Formal inference rules for functional dependencies: Armstrong’s axioms: 1. Reflexivity: If Y ⊆ X then X -> Y (called trivial FD); 2. Transitivity: If X -> Y and Y -> Z then X -> Z; 3. Augmentation: If X -> Y then XZ -> YZ where Z is a set of attributes. '''Where do FDs come from?''' looking either at (1) Domain Knowledge (the meaning of the attributes); (2) the data; {| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- !a|| b|| c |- | 1 || 2 || 3 |- | 4 || 2 || 6 |} b->a is not FD, but a->b is a valid FD. == BCNF == '''Formal way to break tables:''' {| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- !gene|| name|| annotation || experiment id || experiment description || experiment level |- |...|| ...|| ... || ... || ... || ... |} ⇒ R1 (gid, name, annotation); gid->name annotation; R2 (exp id, exp desc); exp id -> exp desc; R3 (gid, expid, exp level); gid, expid -> exp level; Original Relation -> find\ \ a \ FD \ X->Y \left\{ \begin{array}{ll} {X, Y}, & \hbox{gid, name, annotation;} \\ {everything\ \ except Y}, & \hbox{gid, exp id, exp desc, exp level;} \end{array} \right. gid, exp id, exp desc, exp level \left\{ \begin{array}{ll} {exp id, exp desc}, & \hbox{;} \\ {gid, \ exp id, \ exp level }, & \hbox{;} \end{array} \right. A relation R is in BCNF if for all dependencies X -> Y , at least one of the following holds: • X -> Y is a trivial FD (Y ⊆ X) • X is a superkey for R == 3NF == Formal Definition: a relation R is in 3NF if for all dependencies X® Y in F+, at least one of the following holds: • X -> Y is a trivial FD (Y ⊆ X) • X is a superkey for R • Y ⊂ a candidate key for R == Comparison of BCNF and 3NF == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- | !Removes
Redundancy !Preserves
FDs !Lossless
Decomposition |- !BCNF |Yes ||No ||Yes |- !3NF |No ||Yes ||Yes |} == Lossy Decomposition == Suppose we have a table such as the one below. {| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- !a || b || c |- | 1 || 2 || 3 |- | 4 || 2 || 6 |} into the following "normalized" tables
{| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- !a || b |- | 1 || 2 |- | 4 || 2 |} {| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- !b || c |- |2 || 3 |- |2 || 6 |}
This means we followed : b → a or : b → c as our FD for the decomposition of the original table. (Remember, BCNF decomposes X → Y to the sets {X, Y} and {everything except Y}). However, notice that column b has non-unique values (two of digit 2). When we recombine these two tables in a join, we wind up with a table in which the original relationships are lost: {| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- !a || b || c |- | 1 || 2 || 3 |- | 1 || 2 || 6 |- | 4 || 2 || 3 |- | 4 || 2 || 6 |} We declare this as a '''lossy decomposition''', because the FDs assumed by the decomposed tables do not hold true (both b → a and b → c are false). Thus, BCNF can not remove all forms of redundancy. We will need to use another model, Multivalued Dependency (MD), to aid us in decomposing tables properly for normalization. = Multivalued Dependency (MD) = Let's explore a concrete scenario. We'd like to represent belongings of affluent students. We create a '''multivalued dependency (MD)''' of : SID →→ car read as, "A given student ID can have many cars." Compare this to an FD like : SID → name which we read as, "A given SID can have at most one name." Suppose we also had the following MD: : SID →→ clothes We can get the following table: {| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- !SID || car || clothes |- | 1 || Honda || jeans |- | 1 || Toyota || khakis |- | 1 || Toyota || jeans |- | 1 || Honda || khakis |- | … || … || … |} Perhaps we want to decompose this table further. We decompose along the MD of : SID →→ car This leaves us with {SID, clothes}, leaving us with the following tables
SID →→ car {SID, clothes}
{| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- !SID || car |- | 1 || Honda |- | 1 || Toyota |- | … || … |} {| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- !sid || clothes |- |1 || jeans |- |1 || khakis |- | … || … |}
We can't ''actually'' do this, because these are ''not'' FDs! Neither SID →→ car or SID →→ clothes have a superkey. The key must be all three attributes. We need new rules for decomposing MDs. == Rules for MDs == === Spotting trivial MDs === We say that an MD {{math|X →→ Y}} is trivial in {{math|R}} if {{math|X ∪ Y {{=}} {all attributes} }}. For example, consider the following relation {{math|R1}} where we have the MD {{math|a →→ b}}: {| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- |colspan="2" | {{math|R1}} |- ! a || b |- |1 || 2 |- |1 || 3 |- |2 || 2 |- | … || … |} Because we can have many {{math|b}}s to each {{math|a}}, we can not generate data to violate the MD. Now consider the following relation {{math|R2}}: {| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- |colspan="3" | {{math|R3}} |- ! a || b || c |- |1 || 2 || 6 |- |1 || 3 || 7 |- |2 || 2 || 6 |- | … || … || … |} In this case, {{math|a →→ b}} is non-trivial, because the relation is three-way. === Non-trivial MDs come in pairs === In fact, {{math|a →→ b}} has a partner MD which is also non-trivial: {{math|a →→ c}} Here are the listings of all non-trivial pairs of MDs in {{math|R2}} {| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- | {| |- |{{math|a →→ b}} |- |{{math|a →→ c}} |} |- | {| |{{math|b →→ a}} |- |{{math|b →→ c}} |} |- | {| |{{math|c →→ a}} |- |{{math|c →→ b}} |} |} Compare this to examples of trivial MDs for {{math|R2}}: {| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- |{{math|a →→ bc}} |- |{{math|ab →→ c}} |- |{{math|b →→ ac}} |- |{{math|bc →→ a}} |- |{{math|c →→ ab}} |- |{{math|ca →→ b}} |- |… |} === Implications of FDs do not hold for MDs === In FDs, we know X \rightarrow YZ \iff \begin{array}{c} X \rightarrow Y \\ \mbox{and} \\ X \rightarrow Z \end{array} However, this same implication does not exist for MDs. That is, X \rightarrow\rightarrow YZ \nLeftrightarrow \begin{array}{c} X \rightarrow\rightarrow Y \\ \mbox{and} \\ X \rightarrow\rightarrow Z \end{array} === MDs are actually about independence === Given the MDs : {{math|a →→ b}} : and : {{math|a →→ c}} We know that, for each {{math|a}} * there can be many {{math|a}} * there can be many {{math|a}} * and, {{math|b}}s are independent of {{math|c}}s with respect to {{math|a}}, which we represent symbolically as b \perp c | a [NOTE: the actual first binary relation symbol should be \Perp instead of \perp, but this symbol is not supported by Mediawiki.] === Every FD is an MD === By definition, {{math|X → Y ⇒ X →→ Y}}. If {{math|X}} has at most one {{math|Y}}, then it satisfies the condition of having many {{math|Y}}. For example, given the following relation {| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- ! a || b |- | … || … |} and an FD of {{math|a → b}}, then we also have a trivial MD of {{math|a →→ b}}. Now, consider the FD {{math|a → b}} with following relation: {| border="1" cellpadding="4" style="margin: 1em auto" |- ! a || b || c || d |- | … || … || … || … |} In this case, we actually have two ''non''-trivial MDs: {| |- |{{math|a →→ b}} |- |{{math|a →→ cd}} |} (Remember, [[#Non-trivial_MDs_come_in_pairs|non-trivial MDs come in pairs]].) [[Category:Data Management in Bioinformatics]]

<noinclude>{{SbcHeaderSpanishPod|title=Are You Ready yet?|id=A0001}}</noinclude> {{SbcIntroductionSpanishPod}} Sometimes people are just too slow! And then they hurry too much! In this lesson JP and Liliana teach us how to create time pressure and how to react to it and—most importantly—to relax. The keyword is '''tranquila''' – relaxed (for feminine nouns). {{SbcSourceSpanishPod|[[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0013|A0013: Doing the laundry]], [[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0041|A0041: Cheers!]], [[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0127|A0127: Flirting]]}} <noinclude>{{SbcAudioSpanishPod|title=Are you ready yet?|id=A0001|dialogueid=A0001 dialogue}}</noinclude> {{SbcDialogueSpanishPod}} :{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''¿Ya estás lista?''' <noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0001 line 1}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''¡Espera un momento!''' <noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0001 line 2}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''Tranquila. Todavía tenemos tiempo.''' <noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0001 line 3}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''Menos mal.''' <noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0001 line 4}}</noinclude> |- |}
{{SbcDialogueWithTranslationSpanishPod}} :{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''¿Ya''' || '''estás''' || '''lista?''' <noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0001 line 1}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| ||''already'' || ''(you) are'' || ''ready'' |- |align="right"|''man:'' ||colspan=3|Are you ready yet? |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''¡Espera''' || '''un''' || '''momento!''' <noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0001 line 2}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| || ''(you) wait'' || ''a'' || ''moment'' |- |align="right"|''woman:'' ||colspan=3| Wait a moment! |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''Tranquila.''' || '''Todavía''' || '''tenemos''' || '''tiempo.''' <noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0001 line 3}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| || ''relaxed'' || ''still'' || ''(we) have'' || ''time'' |- |align="right"|''man:'' ||colspan=4| Relax! We still have time. |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''Menos''' || '''mal.''' <noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0001 line 4}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| || ''less'' || ''badly'' |- |align="right"|''woman:'' ||colspan=2| Good. |- |}
{{Wikipedia|tiempo (song)}} [[Image:BenboisClock.svg|thumb|right|'''el tiempo''' – the time|120px]] ===Vocabulary for Dialogue=== :{| |- || '''el hombre''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the man |- || '''la mujer''' || {{SbcNounF}} || the woman |- || '''ya''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || already |- || '''estar''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to be |- || '''(tú) estás'''|| {{SbcVerbPT}} || you are (informal, singular) |- || '''listo/lista''' || {{SbcAdjectiveMF}} || ready |- || '''esperar'''|| {{SbcVerbInf}} || to wait |- || '''¡(tú) espera!''' || {{SbcVerbImp}} || (you) wait! (informal, singular) |- || '''un/una'''|| {{SbcArticleMF}} || a |- || '''el momento''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the moment |- || '''tranquilo/tranquila''' || {{SbcAdjectiveMF}} || relaxed, calm |- || '''todavía''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || still |- || '''tener''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to have |- || '''(nosotros/-as) tenemos''' || {{SbcVerbPT}} || we have |- || '''el tiempo''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the time |- || '''menos'''|| {{SbcAdverb}} || less |- || '''mal'''|| {{SbcAdverb}} || badly |- || '''menos mal''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || OK, good |- |}
[[Image:Rainbow_over_Becerril.jpg|thumb|right|'''el tiempo''' – the weather|160px]] ===Vocabulary for Audio Lesson=== :{| |- || '''el tiempo''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the time, the weather |- || '''¿cómo?''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || how? |- || '''¿Cómo está el tiempo?''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || How is the weather? |- || '''el clima'''|| {{SbcNounM}} || the climate, the weather |- || '''tranquilos/tranquilas''' || {{SbcAdjectivePMF}} || relaxed, calm |- || '''¡(usted) espere!''' || {{SbcVerbImp}} || (you) wait! (formal, singular) |- || '''¡(ustedes) esperen!''' || {{SbcVerbImp}} || (you) wait! (formal, plural) |- |}
{{SbcMoreVocabularySpanishPod}} {| |- |align="right"| '''esperar'''|| {{SbcInf}} || to wait |- |align="right"| '''¡(tú) espera!'''|| {{SbcImp}} || (you) wait! (informal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''¡(usted) espere!''' || || (you) wait! (formal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''¡(nosotros/-as) esperemos!''' || || (let's) wait! (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''¡(vosotros/-as) esperad!''' || || (you) wait! (informal, plural, m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''¡(ustedes) esperen!'''|| || (you) wait! (formal, plural) |- ||   || |- |align="right"| '''estar''' || {{SbcInf}} || to be |- |align="right"| '''(yo) estoy''' || {{SbcPT}} || I am |- |align="right"| '''(tú) estás''' || || you are (informal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(él/ella) está''' || || he/she(/it) is |- |align="right"| '''(usted) está''' || || you are (formal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(nosotros/-as) estamos''' || || we are (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(vosotros/-as) estáis''' || || you are (informal, plural, m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ellos/ellas) están''' || || they are (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ustedes) están''' || || you are (formal, plural) |- ||   || |- |align="right"| '''tener''' || {{SbcInf}} || to have |- |align="right"| '''(yo) tengo''' || {{SbcPT}} || I have |- |align="right"| '''(tú) tienes''' || || you have (informal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(él/ella) tiene''' || || he/she(/it) has |- |align="right"| '''(usted) tiene''' || || you have (formal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(nosotros/-as) tenemos'''|| || we have (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(vosotros/-as) tenéis'''|| || you have (informal, plural, m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ellos/ellas) tienen'''|| || they have (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ustedes) tienen''' || || you have (formal, plural) |- |}
{{SbcExercisesSpanishPod}} <noinclude>====Dialogue Translation==== Translate from Spanish to English. Click each bar to check your answer. If possible, read the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestion | '''¿Ya estás lista?''' | Are you ready yet? | '''¡Espera un momento!''' | Wait a moment! | '''Tranquila. Todavía tenemos tiempo.''' | Relax! We still have time. | '''Menos mal.''' | Good./Less bad. }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Translation==== Cover the right column, translate from Spanish to English and uncover the right column line by line to check your answers. If possible, read the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestionPrint | '''¿Ya estás lista?''' | Are you ready yet? | '''¡Espera un momento!''' | Wait a moment! | '''Tranquila. Todavía tenemos tiempo.''' | Relax! We still have time. | '''Menos mal.''' | Good./Less bad. }}</includeonly> <noinclude>====Dialogue Recall==== Now translate from English to Spanish. Remember to say the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestion | Are you ready yet? | '''¿Ya estás listo/lista?''' | Wait a moment! | '''¡Espera un momento!''' | Relax! We still have time. | '''Tranquilo/tranquila. Todavía tenemos tiempo.''' | Good ({{=}} less bad). | '''Menos mal.''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Recall==== Now translate from English to Spanish. Remember to say the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestionPrint | Are you ready yet? | '''¿Ya estás listo/lista?''' | Wait a moment! | '''¡Espera un momento!''' | Relax! We still have time. | '''Tranquilo/tranquila. Todavía tenemos tiempo.''' | Good ({{=}} less bad). | '''Menos mal.''' }}</includeonly> {{SbcNewline}}{{SbcNewline}}<noinclude>====Dialogue Remix==== Translate this variant of the dialogue from English to Spanish. {{SbcQuestion | Do we have time? | '''¿Tenemos tiempo?''' | We still have time. | '''Todavía tenemos tiempo.''' | Do we still have a moment? | '''¿Todavía tenemos un momento?''' | We still have a moment. | '''Todavía tenemos un momento.''' | Are you ready? | '''¿Estás listo/lista?''' | Wait a moment! | '''¡Espera un momento!''' | Relax! We still have time. | '''Tranquilo/tranquila. Todavía tenemos tiempo.''' | Good ({{=}} less bad). | '''Menos mal.''' | Are you already relaxed? | '''¿Ya estás tranquilo/tranquila?''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Remix==== Translate this variant of the dialogue from English to Spanish. {{SbcQuestionPrint | Do we have time? | '''¿Tenemos tiempo?''' | We still have time. | '''Todavía tenemos tiempo.''' | Do we still have a moment? | '''¿Todavía tenemos un momento?''' | We still have a moment. | '''Todavía tenemos un momento.''' | Are you ready? | '''¿Estás listo/lista?''' | Wait a moment! | '''¡Espera un momento!''' | Relax! We still have time. | '''Tranquilo/tranquila. Todavía tenemos tiempo.''' | Good ({{=}} less bad). | '''Menos mal.''' | Are you already relaxed? | '''¿Ya estás tranquilo/tranquila?''' }}</includeonly> <noinclude>====Dialogue Recast==== This translation exercise requires some of the words from the [[#More Vocabulary|More Vocabulary]] section. {{SbcQuestion | Are you ready yet? (formal) | '''¿Ya está listo/lista (usted)?''' | Wait a moment! (formal) | '''¡Espere un momento!''' | Relax! I still have time. | '''Tranquilo/tranquila. Todavía tengo tiempo.''' | Good ({{=}} less bad). | '''Menos mal.''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Recast==== This translation exercise requires some of the words from the More Vocabulary section. {{SbcQuestionPrint | Are you ready yet? (formal) | '''¿Ya está listo/lista (usted)?''' | Wait a moment! (formal) | '''¡Espere un momento!''' | Relax! I still have time. | '''Tranquilo/tranquila. Todavía tengo tiempo.''' | Good ({{=}} less bad). | '''Menos mal.''' }}</includeonly>

revision.text:
== Welcome message == Hello, and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]! Here are some tips to [[Help|help]] you get started: * To learn the wiki-markup-language syntax, see [[Help:Editing]]. * Make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes, like this: ~~~~ **There is a box at the top of the edit window (if javascript is enabled on your browser) that will insert it too (looks like part of a signature). This will let others know who left it, and make it easy to reply back to you. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * You can tell the community something about yourself in your userpage. ** You can get to this page by clicking the tab at the top of the page labeled with your registered username. * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. ([[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks]]). * If you are a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]] (requests for importation) to bring the material over in compliance with the GFDL. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using Wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Help us by participating in policy and guideline creation. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun! You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or [[User_talk:Panic2k4|ask me personally on my talk page]]. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be a good idea to add that page to your "[[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]]" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. You can do that by clicking the tab labeled "watch" at the top of the page. Good luck! --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 17:41, 16 September 2008 (UTC) {{mbox|type=warning|msg='''Wikibooks regretfully cannot accept [[Wikibooks:Copyrights|copyrighted]] materials.'''
We [[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]] and appreciate your contributions. If [[:Cookbook:Casquinha de Siri]] uses an acceptable copyleft license or the copyright holders are willing to give [[Wikibooks:Boilerplate_request_for_permission|permission]] to use it under an acceptable copyleft license, then we need you to include the licensing information with it. Please read [[Wikibooks:Media]] to learn more about our requirements. After 7 days if this is not addressed appropriately we will have to delete it [[WB:COPYVIO|per policy]]. If you have any questions you can ask me personally or ask in the [[WB:HELP|reading room]]. Thank you; Happy editing!  '''— [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 17:35, 18 September 2008 (UTC)}}

== Welcome message ==
Hello, and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Here are some tips to [[Help|help]] you get started: * To learn the wiki-markup-language syntax, see [[Help:Editing]]. * Make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes, like this: ~~~~ **There is a box at the top of the edit window (if javascript is enabled on your browser) that will insert it too (looks like part of a signature). This will let others know who left it, and make it easy to reply back to you. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * You can tell the community something about yourself in your userpage. ** You can get to this page by clicking the tab at the top of the page labeled with your registered username. * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. ([[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks]]). * If you are a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]] (requests for importation) to bring the material over in compliance with the GFDL. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using Wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Help us by participating in policy and guideline creation. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or [[User_talk:Panic2k4|ask me personally on my talk page]]. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be a good idea to add that page to your "[[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]]" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. You can do that by clicking the tab labeled "watch" at the top of the page.
Good luck! --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 17:41, 16 September 2008 (UTC)
