page.title: Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0007

revision.text:
<noinclude>{{SbcHeaderSpanishPod|title=Where Are You From?|id=A0007}}</noinclude> {{SbcIntroductionSpanishPod}} Yes, this is about the easiest way to find something to talk about: asking where people are from. Invaluable small talk strategies offered by Liliana and JP. Keywords are '''Perú''' – Peru and '''Colombia''' – Colombia. {{SbcSourceSpanishPod|[[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0006|A0006: How's it going?]], [[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0047|A0047: Coffee time]], [[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0082|A0082: My name is...]]}} <noinclude>{{SbcAudioSpanishPod|title=Where Are You From?|id=A0007|dialogueid=A0007 dialogue}}</noinclude> {{SbcDialogueSpanishPod}} :{| |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''¿De dónde eres?'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0007 line 1}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''Soy de Perú. ¿Y tú?'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0007 line 2}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''Yo soy de Colombia.'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0007 line 3}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''¡Qué bien!'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0007 line 4}}</noinclude> |- |}
{{SbcDialogueWithTranslationSpanishPod}} :{| |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''¿De''' || '''dónde''' || '''eres?'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0007 line 1}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| || ''from'' || ''where'' || ''(you) are'' |- |align="right"|''woman:'' ||colspan=3| Where are you from? |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''Soy''' || '''de''' || '''Perú.''' || '''¿Y''' || '''tú?''' <noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0007 line 2}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| ||''(I) am'' || ''from'' || ''Peru'' || ''and'' || ''you'' |- |align="right"|''man:'' ||colspan=5| I'm from Peru. And you? |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''Yo''' || '''soy''' || '''de''' || '''Colombia.'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0007 line 3}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| || ''I'' || ''am'' || ''from'' || ''Colombia'' |- |align="right"|''woman:'' ||colspan=4| I'm from Colombia. |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''¡Qué''' || '''bien!''' <noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0007 line 4}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| ||''how'' || ''good'' |- |align="right"|''man:'' ||colspan=3| How nice! |- |}
{{Wikipedia|Peru}}{{Wikipedia|Colombia}}{{Wikipedia|ceviche}}{{Wikipedia|Inca}}{{Wikipedia|Machu Picchu}}{{Wikipedia|Gabriel García Márquez}}{{Wikipedia|Shakira}} ===Vocabulary for Dialogue=== :{| |- || '''la mujer''' || {{SbcNounF}} || the woman |- || '''el hombre''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the man |- || '''de''' || {{SbcPreposition}} || from, of |- || '''¿dónde?''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || where? |- || '''¿de dónde?''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || from where? |- || '''ser''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to be |- || '''(tú) eres''' || {{SbcVerbPT}} || you are (informal, singular) |- || '''(yo) soy''' || {{SbcVerbPT}} || I am |- || '''Perú''' || {{SbcNounM}} || Peru |- || '''y''' || {{SbcConjunction}} || and |- || '''tú''' || {{SbcSubjectPronoun}} || you (informal, singular) |- || '''yo''' || {{SbcSubjectPronoun}} || I |- || '''Colombia''' || {{SbcNounF}} || Colombia |- || '''¿qué?''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || how?, what? |- || '''bien''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || well, good |- |}
===Vocabulary for Audio Lesson=== :{| |- || '''el ceviche''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the citrus-marinated seafood salad |- || '''los incas''' || {{SbcNounPM}} || the Incas |- || '''Machu Picchu''' || {{SbcNounM}} || a Inca city |- || '''Gabriel García Márquez''' || {{SbcNounM}} || a Colombian writer |- || '''Shakira Isabel Mebarak Ripoll''' || {{SbcNounF}} || a Colombian goddess |- || '''hasta luego''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || see you later |- |}
{{SbcMoreVocabularySpanishPod}} {| |- |align="right"| '''ser''' || {{SbcInf}} || to be |- |align="right"| '''(yo) soy''' || {{SbcPT}} || I am |- |align="right"| '''(tú) eres''' || || you are (informal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(él/ella) es''' || || he/she(/it) is |- |align="right"| '''(usted) es''' || || you are (formal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(nosotros/-as) somos'''|| || we are (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(vosotros/-as) sois'''|| || you are (informal, plural, m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ellos/ellas) son'''|| || they are (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ustedes) son''' || || you are (formal, plural) |- |}
{{SbcExercisesSpanishPod}} <noinclude>====Dialogue Translation==== Translate from Spanish to English. Click each bar to check your answer. If possible, read the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestion | '''¿De dónde eres?''' | Where are you from? | '''Soy de Perú. ¿Y tú?''' | I'm from Peru. And you? | '''Yo soy de Colombia.''' | I'm from Colombia. | '''¡Qué bien!''' | How nice! }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Translation==== Cover the right column, translate from Spanish to English and uncover the right column line by line to check your answers. If possible, read the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestionPrint | '''¿De dónde eres?''' | Where are you from? | '''Soy de Perú. ¿Y tú?''' | I'm from Peru. And you? | '''Yo soy de Colombia.''' | I'm from Colombia. | '''¡Qué bien!''' | How nice! }}</includeonly> <noinclude>====Dialogue Recall==== Now translate from English to Spanish. Remember to say the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestion | Where are you from? | '''¿De dónde eres?''' | I'm from Peru. And you? | '''Soy de Perú. ¿Y tú?''' | I'm from Colombia. | '''Yo soy de Colombia.''' | How nice! | '''¡Qué bien!''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Recall==== Now translate from English to Spanish. Remember to say the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestionPrint | Where are you from? | '''¿De dónde eres?''' | I'm from Peru. And you? | '''Soy de Perú. ¿Y tú?''' | I'm from Colombia. | '''Yo soy de Colombia.''' | How nice! | '''¡Qué bien!''' }}</includeonly> <noinclude>====Dialogue Remix==== Translate this variant of the dialogue from English to Spanish. {{SbcQuestion | Where are you from? | '''¿De dónde eres?''' | Where am I from? | '''¿De dónde soy?''' | From Peru, from Colombia, ...? | '''¿De Perú, de Colombia, ...?''' | Are you from Peru? | '''¿(Tú) eres de Perú?''' | I'm from Colombia. | '''(Yo) soy de Colombia.''' | How nice! | '''¡Qué bien!''' | And you? | '''¿Y tú?''' | What? | '''¿Qué?''' | Where are you from? | '''¿De dónde eres?''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Remix==== Translate this variant of the dialogue from English to Spanish. {{SbcQuestionPrint | Where are you from? | '''¿De dónde eres?''' | Where am I from? | '''¿De dónde soy?''' | From Peru, from Colombia, ...? | '''¿De Perú, de Colombia, ...?''' | Are you from Peru? | '''¿(Tú) eres de Perú?''' | I'm from Colombia. | '''(Yo) soy de Colombia.''' | How nice! | '''¡Qué bien!''' | And you? | '''¿Y tú?''' | What? | '''¿Qué?''' | Where are you from? | '''¿De dónde eres?''' }}</includeonly> <noinclude>====Dialogue Recast==== This translation exercise requires some of the words from the [[#More Vocabulary|More Vocabulary]] section. {{SbcQuestion | Where are you from? (formal) | '''¿De dónde es (usted)?''' | I'm from Peru. And you? (formal, plural) | '''Soy de Perú. ¿Y ustedes?''' | We are from Colombia. | '''Nosotros somos de Colombia.''' | How nice! | '''¡Qué bien!''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Recast==== This translation exercise requires some of the words from the More Vocabulary section. {{SbcQuestionPrint | Where are you from? (formal) | '''¿De dónde es (usted)?''' | I'm from Peru. And you? (formal, plural) | '''Soy de Perú. ¿Y ustedes?''' | We are from Colombia. | '''Nosotros somos de Colombia.''' | How nice! | '''¡Qué bien!''' }}</includeonly> <noinclude>
{{SbcNavigateSpanishPod|A0006|A0007|A0008}}</noinclude>

page.title: Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0008

revision.text:
<noinclude>{{SbcHeaderSpanishPod|title=How Do You Say ...?|id=A0008}}</noinclude> {{SbcIntroductionSpanishPod}} Did you ever wonder how to say a particular word in Spanish? In this lesson, JP and Liliana tell us how to ask: “How do you say ... in Spanish?”—in Spanish that is. And that's also one of the keywords: '''el español''' – the Spanish language. The other keyword is: '''el inglés''' – the English language. {{SbcSourceSpanishPod|[[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0004|A0004: She's not Mexican]], [[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0005|A0005: Take a picture]], [[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0019|A0019: How do you spell beige?]]}} <noinclude>{{SbcAudioSpanishPod|title=How Do You Say ...?|id=A0008|dialogueid=A0008 dialogue}}</noinclude> {{SbcDialogueSpanishPod}} :{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''¡Oye! ¿Cómo se dice internet en español?'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0008 line 1}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''Se dice internet.'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0008 line 2}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''¿Igual que en inglés?'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0008 line 3}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''Sí, igual.'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0008 line 4}}</noinclude> |- |}
{{SbcDialogueWithTranslationSpanishPod}} :{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''¡Oye!''' || '''¿Cómo''' || '''se''' || '''dice''' || '''internet''' || '''en''' || '''español?'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0008 line 1}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| ||''listen'' || ''how'' || ''itself/one'' || ''says'' || ''internet'' || ''in'' || ''Spanish'' |- |align="right"|''man:'' ||colspan=7| Hey! How do you say internet in Spanish? |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''Se''' || '''dice''' || '''internet.'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0008 line 2}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| || ''itself/one'' || ''says'' || ''internet'' |- |align="right"|''woman:'' ||colspan=3| You say internet. |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''¿Igual''' || '''que''' || '''en''' || '''inglés?'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0008 line 3}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| || ''equal'' || ''as'' || ''in'' || ''English'' |- |align="right"|''man:'' ||colspan=4| The same as in English? |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''Sí,''' || '''igual.'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0008 line 4}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| || ''yes'' || ''equal'' |- |align="right"|''woman:'' ||colspan=2| Yes, the same. |- |}
{{Wikipedia|español}}[[Image:Flag of Spain.svg|thumb|'''el español''' – the Spanish|160px]] ===Vocabulary for Dialogue=== :{| |- || '''el hombre''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the man |- || '''la mujer''' || {{SbcNounF}} || the woman |- || '''oír''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to hear |- || '''¡(tú) oye!''' || {{SbcVerbImp}} || (you) hear, listen! (informal, singular) |- || '''¿cómo?''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || how? |- || '''se''' || {{SbcReflexivePronoun}} || itself, one, you |- || '''decir''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to say |- || '''(él/ella) dice''' || {{SbcVerbPT}} || he/she(/it) says |- || '''el internet''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the internet |- || '''en''' || {{SbcPreposition}} || in |- || '''el español''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the Spanish |- || '''igual''' || {{SbcAdjectiveMF}} || equal, same |- || '''que''' || {{SbcConjunction}} || as, than |- || '''el inglés''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the English |- || '''sí''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || yes |- |}
{{Wikipedia|hot dog variations}}[[Image:NCI Visuals Food Hot Dog.jpg|thumb|'''el perro caliente''' – the hot dog|160px]] ===Vocabulary for Audio Lesson=== :{| |- || '''¿Cómo se dice ...?''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || How do you say ...? |- || '''la pluma''' || {{SbcNounF}} || the pen |- || '''el anglicismo''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the anglicism |- || '''los anglicismos''' || {{SbcNounPM}} || the anglicisms |- || '''hacer''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to make |- || '''hacer clic''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || to click |- || '''el perro caliente''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || the hot dog |- || '''ser''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to be |- || '''(él) es''' || {{SbcVerbPT}} || he is |- || '''muy''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || very |- || '''Él es muy nerd.''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || He is a nerd. |- || '''este/esta''' || {{SbcPronoun}} ''(m./f.)'' || that |- || '''la situación''' || {{SbcNounF}}|| the situation |- || '''friky''' || {{SbcAdjectiveMF}} || freaky |- || '''Esta situación es muy friky.''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || That situation is very freaky. |- |}
{{SbcMoreVocabularySpanishPod}} {| |- |align="right"| '''oír''' || {{SbcInf}}|| to hear |- |align="right"| '''¡(tú) oye!''' || {{SbcImp}}|| (you) hear! (informal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''¡(usted) oiga!''' || || (you) hear! (formal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''¡(nosotros/-as) oigamos!''' || || (let's) hear! (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''¡(vosotros/-as) oíd!''' || || (you) hear! (informal, plural, m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''¡(ustedes) oigan!''' || || (you) hear! (formal, plural) |- ||   || |- |align="right"| '''decir''' || {{SbcInf}} ||to say |- |align="right"| '''(yo) digo''' || {{SbcPT}} || I say |- |align="right"| '''(tú) dices''' || || you say (informal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(él/ella) dice''' || || he/she(/it) says |- |align="right"| '''(usted) dice''' || || you say (formal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(nosotros/-as) decimos''' || || we say (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(vosotros/-as) decís''' || || you say (informal, plural, m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ellos/ellas) dicen''' || || they say (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ustedes) dicen''' || || you say (formal, plural) |- |}
{{SbcExercisesSpanishPod}} <noinclude>====Dialogue Translation==== Translate from Spanish to English. Click each bar to check your answer. If possible, read the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestion | '''¡Oye! ¿Cómo se dice internet en español?''' | Hey! How do you say internet in Spanish? | '''Se dice internet.''' | You say internet. | '''¿Igual que en inglés?''' | The same as in English? | '''Sí, igual.''' | Yes, the same. }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Translation==== Cover the right column, translate from Spanish to English and uncover the right column line by line to check your answers. If possible, read the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestionPrint | '''¡Oye! ¿Cómo se dice internet en español?''' | Hey! How do you say internet in Spanish? | '''Se dice internet.''' | You say internet. | '''¿Igual que en inglés?''' | The same as in English? | '''Sí, igual.''' | Yes, the same. }}</includeonly> <noinclude>====Dialogue Recall==== Now translate from English to Spanish. Remember to say the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestion | Listen! How do you say internet in Spanish? | '''¡Oye! ¿Cómo se dice internet en español?''' | You say internet. | '''Se dice internet.''' | The same as in English? | '''¿Igual que en inglés?''' | Yes, the same. | '''Sí, igual.''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Recall==== Now translate from English to Spanish. Remember to say the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestionPrint | Listen! How do you say internet in Spanish? | '''¡Oye! ¿Cómo se dice internet en español?''' | You say internet. | '''Se dice internet.''' | The same as in English? | '''¿Igual que en inglés?''' | Yes, the same. | '''Sí, igual.''' }}</includeonly> <noinclude>====Dialogue Remix==== Translate this variant of the dialogue from English to Spanish. {{SbcQuestion | How do you say tequila in Spanish? | '''¿Cómo se dice tequila en español?''' | How? | '''¿Cómo?''' (short for '''¿Cómo dice?''' – What do you say? (formal)) | How do you say tequila? | '''¿Cómo se dice tequila?''' | Tequila. It is Spanish! | '''Tequila. ¡Es español!''' | One says tequila in Spanish? | '''¿Se dice tequila en español?''' | Yes, you say tequila. | '''Sí, se dice tequila.''' | The same as in English! | '''¡Igual que en inglés!''' | Yes, the same. | '''Sí, igual.''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Remix==== Translate this variant of the dialogue from English to Spanish. {{SbcQuestionPrint | How do you say tequila in Spanish? | '''¿Cómo se dice tequila en español?''' | How? | '''¿Cómo?''' (short for '''¿Cómo dice?''' – What do you say? (formal)) | How do you say tequila? | '''¿Cómo se dice tequila?''' | Tequila. It is Spanish! | '''Tequila. ¡Es español!''' | One says tequila in Spanish? | '''¿Se dice tequila en español?''' | Yes, you say tequila. | '''Sí, se dice tequila.''' | The same as in English! | '''¡Igual que en inglés!''' | Yes, the same. | '''Sí, igual.''' }}</includeonly> {{SbcNewline}}{{SbcNewline}}<noinclude>====Dialogue Recast==== This translation exercise requires some of the words from the [[#More Vocabulary|More Vocabulary]] section. {{SbcQuestion | Listen! How do you say internet in Spanish? (formal) | '''¡Oiga! ¿Cómo se dice internet en español?''' | You say internet. | '''Se dice internet.''' | The same as in English? | '''¿Igual que en inglés?''' | Yes, the same. | '''Sí, igual.''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Recast==== This translation exercise requires some of the words from the More Vocabulary section. {{SbcQuestionPrint | Listen! How do you say internet in Spanish? (formal) | '''¡Oiga! ¿Cómo se dice internet en español?''' | You say internet. | '''Se dice internet.''' | The same as in English? | '''¿Igual que en inglés?''' | Yes, the same. | '''Sí, igual.''' }}</includeonly>
<includeonly>===Image Credits=== *“Image:Flag of Spain.svg” by Pedro A. Gracia Fajardo (Creative Commons Public Domain Dedication) *“Image:NCI Visuals Food Hot Dog.jpg” by Renee Comet (Public Domain)</includeonly> <noinclude>{{SbcNavigateSpanishPod|A0007|A0008|A0010}}</noinclude>

page.title: Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0011

revision.text:
<noinclude>{{SbcHeaderSpanishPod|title=Call Me|id=A0011}}</noinclude> {{SbcIntroductionSpanishPod}} In this lesson, Liliana and JP tell us how to say goodbye and a lot of other very useful phrases, such as “right?”, “when?”, “let's see”, “I don't know”, “call me!”, and “OK”. The keyword is one of them: '''llámame''' – call me. {{SbcSourceSpanishPod|[[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0019|A0019: How do you spell beige?]], [[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0030|A0030: Call back later]], [[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0086|A0086: Are you single?]]}} <noinclude>{{SbcAudioSpanishPod|title=Call Me|id=A0011|dialogueid=A0011 dialogue}}</noinclude> {{SbcDialogueSpanishPod}} :{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''Nos vemos mañana, ¿no?'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0011 line 1}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''¿A qué hora?'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0011 line 2}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''A ver, no sé. Llámame más tarde.'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0011 line 3}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''Vale. Hasta mañana.'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0011 line 4}}</noinclude> |- |}
{{SbcDialogueWithTranslationSpanishPod}} :{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''Nos''' || '''vemos''' || '''mañana,''' || '''¿no?'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0011 line 1}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| ||''(to) each other'' || ''we see'' || ''tomorrow'' || ''no'' |- |align="right"|''man:'' ||colspan=4| We see each other tomorrow, right? |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''¿A''' || '''qué''' || '''hora?'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0011 line 2}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| || ''at'' || ''what'' || ''hour'' |- |align="right"|''woman:'' ||colspan=3| At what time? |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''A''' || '''ver,''' || '''no''' || '''sé.''' || '''Llámame''' || '''más''' || '''tarde.'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0011 line 3}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| || ''to'' || ''see'' || ''no'' || ''(I) know'' || ''(you) call me'' || ''more'' || ''late'' |- |align="right"|''man:'' ||colspan=7| Let's see. I don't know. Call me later. |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''Vale.''' || '''Hasta''' || '''mañana.'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0011 line 4}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| || ''(it) is valid'' || ''until'' || ''tomorrow'' |- |align="right"|''woman:'' ||colspan=3| OK, see you tomorrow. |- |}
{{Wikipedia|mañana (song)}}{{Wikipedia|hasta la vista}} [[Image:AndesEarlyAMArgentinoLake.jpg|thumb|'''la mañana''' – the morning|160px]] ===Vocabulary for Dialogue=== :{| |- || '''el hombre''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the man |- || '''la mujer''' || {{SbcNounF}} || the woman |- || '''nos''' || {{SbcReflexivePronoun}} || (to) ourselves, each other |- || '''ver''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to see |- || '''(nosotros/-as) vemos''' || {{SbcVerbPT}} || we see (m./f.) |- || '''nos vemos''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || we see each other |- || '''mañana''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || tomorrow |- || '''la mañana''' || {{SbcNounF}} || the morning |- || '''no''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || no |- || '''a''' || {{SbcPreposition}} || at, to |- || '''¿qué?''' || {{SbcInterrogativePronoun}} || what?, which? |- || '''la hora''' || {{SbcNounF}} || the hour, the time |- || '''a ver''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || let's see |- || '''saber''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to know |- || '''(yo) sé''' || {{SbcVerbPT}} || I know |- || '''llamar''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to call |- || '''me''' || {{SbcDirectPronoun}} || me |- || '''¡(tú) llama!''' || {{SbcVerbImp}} || (you) call! (informal, singular) |- || '''¡(tú) llámame!''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || (you) call me! (informal, singular) |- || '''más''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || more |- || '''tarde''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || late |- || '''más tarde''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || later |- || '''valer''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to be valid, to be worthy |- || '''(él/ella) vale''' || {{SbcVerbPT}} || he/she(/it) is valid, worthy |- || '''vale''' || {{SbcInterjection}} || OK |- || '''hasta''' || {{SbcPreposition}} || until |- |}
[[Image:Cow portrait.jpg|thumb|'''la vaca''' – the cow|120px]] ===Vocabulary for Audio Lesson=== :{| |- || '''la vaca''' || {{SbcNounF}} || the cow |- || '''la uve''' || {{SbcNounF}} || the v |- || '''el burro''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the donkey |- || '''be de burro''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || b as in burro |- || '''be grande''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || big b |- || '''hasta luego''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || see you |- |}
{{SbcMoreVocabularySpanishPod}} {| |- |align="right"| '''me''' || {{SbcReflexivePronoun}}|| myself |- |align="right"| '''te''' || || yourself (informal) |- |align="right"| '''se''' || || himself/herself(/itself) |- |align="right"| '''se''' || || yourself (formal) |- |align="right"| '''nos''' || || ourselves, each other |- |align="right"| '''os''' || || yourselves, each other (informal) |- |align="right"| '''se''' || || themselves, each other |- |align="right"| '''se''' || || yourselves, each other (formal) |- ||   || |- |align="right"| '''ver''' || {{SbcInf}} || to see |- |align="right"| '''(yo) veo''' || {{SbcPT}} || I see |- |align="right"| '''(tú) ves''' || || you see (informal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(él/ella) ve''' || || he/she(/it) sees |- |align="right"| '''(usted) ve''' || || you see (formal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(nosotros/-as) vemos'''|| || we see (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(vosotros/-as) veis'''|| || you see (informal, plural, m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ellos/ellas) ven'''|| || they see (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ustedes) ven''' || || you see (formal, plural) |- ||   || |- |align="right"| '''saber''' || {{SbcInf}} || to know |- |align="right"| '''(yo) sé''' || {{SbcPT}} || I know |- |align="right"| '''(tú) sabes''' || || you know (informal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(él/ella) sabe''' || || he/she(/it) knows |- |align="right"| '''(usted) sabe''' || || you know (formal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(nosotros/-as) sabemos'''|| || we know (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(vosotros/-as) sabéis'''|| || you know (informal, plural, m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ellos/ellas) saben'''|| || they know (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ustedes) saben''' || || you know (formal, plural) |- ||   || |- |align="right"| '''llamar'''|| {{SbcInf}} || to call |- |align="right"| '''¡(tú) llama!'''|| {{SbcImp}} || (you) call! (informal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''¡(usted) llame!''' || || (you) call! (formal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''¡(nosotros/-as) llamemos!''' || || (let's) call! (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''¡(vosotros/-as) llamad!''' || || (you) call! (informal, plural, m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''¡(ustedes) llamen!'''|| || (you) call! (formal, plural) |- ||   || |- |align="right"| '''me'''|| {{SbcDirectPronoun}} || me |- |align="right"| '''te'''|| || you (informal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''lo/la'''|| || him/her(/it) |- |align="right"| '''lo/la'''|| || you (formal, singular, m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''nos'''|| || us |- |align="right"| '''os'''|| || you (informal, plural) |- |align="right"| '''los/las'''|| || them (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''los/las'''|| || you (formal, plural, m./f.) |- ||   || |- |align="right"| '''valer''' || {{SbcInf}} || to be valid, worthy |- |align="right"| '''(yo) valgo''' || {{SbcPT}} || I'm valid |- |align="right"| '''(tú) vales''' || || you are valid (informal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(él/ella) vale''' || || he/she(/it) is valid |- |align="right"| '''(usted) vale''' || || you are valid (formal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(nosotros/-as) valemos'''|| || we are valid (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(vosotros/-as) valéis'''|| || you are valid (informal, plural, m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ellos/ellas) valen'''|| || they are valid (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ustedes) valen''' || || you are valid (formal, plural) |- |}
{{SbcExercisesSpanishPod}} <noinclude>====Dialogue Translation==== Translate from Spanish to English. Click each bar to check your answer. If possible, read the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestion | '''Nos vemos mañana, ¿no?''' | We see each other tomorrow, right? | '''¿A qué hora?''' | At what time? | '''A ver, no sé. Llámame más tarde.''' | Let's see. I don't know. Call me later. | '''Vale. Hasta mañana.''' | OK, see you tomorrow. }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Translation==== Cover the right column, translate from Spanish to English and uncover the right column line by line to check your answers. If possible, read the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestionPrint | '''Nos vemos mañana, ¿no?''' | We see each other tomorrow, right? | '''¿A qué hora?''' | At what time? | '''A ver, no sé. Llámame más tarde.''' | Let's see. I don't know. Call me later. | '''Vale. Hasta mañana.''' | OK, see you tomorrow. }}</includeonly> <noinclude>====Dialogue Recall==== Now translate from English to Spanish. Remember to say the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestion | We see each other tomorrow, right? | '''Nos vemos mañana, ¿no?''' | At what time? | '''¿A qué hora?''' | Let's see. I don't know. Call me later. | '''A ver, no sé. Llámame más tarde.''' | OK, see you tomorrow. | '''Vale. Hasta mañana.''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Recall==== Now translate from English to Spanish. Remember to say the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestionPrint | We see each other tomorrow, right? | '''Nos vemos mañana, ¿no?''' | At what time? | '''¿A qué hora?''' | Let's see. I don't know. Call me later. | '''A ver, no sé. Llámame más tarde.''' | OK, see you tomorrow. | '''Vale. Hasta mañana.''' }}</includeonly> <noinclude>====Dialogue Remix==== Translate this variant of the dialogue from English to Spanish. {{SbcQuestion | When do we see each other? | '''¿A qué hora nos vemos?''' | Let's see. We see each other tomorrow. | '''A ver. Nos vemos mañana. | At what time? | '''¿A qué hora?''' | I don't know. | '''No sé.''' | OK. Call me. | '''Vale. Llámame.''' | OK. When? | '''Vale. ¿A qué hora?''' | I don't know! Later! | '''¡No sé! ¡Más tarde!''' | Tomorrow? | '''¿Mañana?''' | No! | ¡No! }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Remix==== Translate this variant of the dialogue from English to Spanish. {{SbcQuestionPrint | When do we see each other? | '''¿A qué hora nos vemos?''' | Let's see. We see each other tomorrow. | '''A ver. Nos vemos mañana. | At what time? | '''¿A qué hora?''' | I don't know. | '''No sé.''' | OK. Call me. | '''Vale. Llámame.''' | OK. When? | '''Vale. ¿A qué hora?''' | I don't know! Later! | '''¡No sé! ¡Más tarde!''' | Tomorrow? | '''¿Mañana?''' | No! | '''¡No!''' }}</includeonly> <noinclude>====Dialogue Recast==== This translation exercise requires some of the words from the [[#More Vocabulary|More Vocabulary]] section. {{SbcQuestion | They see each other tomorrow, right? | '''Se ven mañana, ¿no?''' | At what time? | '''¿A qué hora?''' | Let's see. They don't know. Call me later. (formal) | '''A ver, no saben. Llámeme más tarde.''' | OK, see you tomorrow. | '''Vale. Hasta mañana.''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Recast==== This translation exercise requires some of the words from the More Vocabulary section. {{SbcQuestionPrint | They see each other tomorrow, right? | '''Se ven mañana, ¿no?''' | At what time? | '''¿A qué hora?''' | Let's see. They don't know. Call me later. (formal) | '''A ver, no saben. Llámeme más tarde.''' | OK, see you tomorrow. | '''Vale. Hasta mañana.''' }}</includeonly>
<includeonly>===Image Credits=== *“Image:AndesEarlyAMArgentinoLake.jpg” by Calyponte (GNU Free Documentation License) *“Image:Cow portrait.jpg” by Pikaluk (Creative Commons Attribution 2.0 License)</includeonly> <noinclude>{{SbcNavigateSpanishPod|A0010|A0011|A0013}}</noinclude>

revision.comment: Removing "Restaurante_Antigua.JPG", it has been deleted from Commons by [[commons:User:Túrelio|Túrelio]] because: [[commons:COM:L|Copyright violation]]: copyvio via http://www.flickr.com/photos/23273032@N00/411631078/in/photostream (2007).
revision.text:
<noinclude>{{SbcHeaderSpanishPod|title=I'm Hungry|id=A0010}}</noinclude> {{SbcIntroductionSpanishPod}} Make sure to eat something before you listen to this lesson. Liliana and JP keep talking about keywords such as '''hambre''' – hunger, '''tengo hambre''' – I'm hungry, and '''restaurante italiano''' – Italian restaurant until they have to stop recording because they are too hungry! {{SbcSourceSpanishPod|[[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0002|A0002: Birthday party]], [[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0015|A0015: Table for two]], [[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0021|A0021: I'm sleepy]], [[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0066|A0066: Bottle of water]]}} <noinclude>{{SbcAudioSpanishPod|title=I'm Hungry|id=A0010|dialogueid=A0010 dialogue}}</noinclude> {{SbcDialogueSpanishPod}} :{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''Tengo hambre.'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0010 line 1}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''Yo también. ¿Vamos a comer?'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0010 line 2}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''Sí, quiero ir a un restaurante italiano.'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0010 line 3}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''Buena idea.'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0010 line 4}}</noinclude> |- |}
{{SbcDialogueWithTranslationSpanishPod}} :{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''Tengo''' || '''hambre.'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0010 line 1}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| ||''(I) have'' || ''hunger'' |- |align="right"|''man:'' ||colspan=2| I'm hungry. |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''Yo''' || '''también.''' || '''¿Vamos''' || '''a''' || '''comer?'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0010 line 2}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| || ''I'' || ''too'' || ''(we) go'' || ''to'' || ''eat'' |- |align="right"|''woman:'' ||colspan=5| Me too. Are we going to eat? |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''Sí,''' || '''quiero''' || '''ir''' || '''a''' || '''un''' || '''restaurante''' || '''italiano.'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0010 line 3}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| ||''yes'' || ''(I) want'' || ''go'' || ''to'' || ''a'' || ''restaurant'' || ''Italian'' |- |align="right"|''man:'' ||colspan=7| Yes, I want to go to a Italian restaurant. |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''Buena''' || '''idea.'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0010 line 4}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| || ''good'' || ''idea'' |- |align="right"|''woman:'' ||colspan=2| Good idea. |- |}
===Vocabulary for Dialogue=== :{| |- || '''el hombre''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the man |- || '''la mujer''' || {{SbcNounF}} || the woman |- || '''tener''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to have |- || '''(yo) tengo''' || {{SbcVerbPT}} || I have |- || '''<u>el ha</u>mbre''' || {{SbcNounF}} || the hunger |- || '''tener hambre''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || to have hunger, to be hungry |- || '''(yo) tengo hambre''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || I have hunger, I'm hungry |- || '''yo''' || {{SbcSubjectPronoun}} || I |- || '''también''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || too, also |- || '''ir''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to go |- || '''(nosotros/-as) vamos''' || {{SbcVerbPT}} || we go (m./f.) |- || '''a''' || {{SbcPreposition}} || to |- || '''comer''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to eat |- || '''sí''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || yes |- || '''querer''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to want, to like, to love |- || '''(yo) quiero''' || {{SbcVerbPT}} || I want |- || '''un/una''' || {{SbcArticleMF}} || a, one |- || '''el restaurante''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the restaurant |- || '''italiano/italiana''' || {{SbcAdjectiveMF}} || Italian |- || '''bueno/buena''' || {{SbcAdjectiveMF}} || good |- || '''la idea''' || {{SbcNounF}} || the idea |- |}
{{Wikipedia|tamarind}}[[Image:Tamarindus indica, leaves, pod.jpg|thumb|'''el tamarindo''' – the tamarind|160px]] ===Vocabulary for Audio Lesson=== :{| |- || '''español/española''' || {{SbcAdjectiveMF}} || Spanish |- || '''francés/francesa''' || {{SbcAdjectiveMF}} || French |- || '''la sed''' || {{SbcNounF}} || the thirst |- || '''tener sed''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || to have thirst, to be thirsty |- || '''(yo) tengo sed''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || I have thirst, I'm thirsty |- || '''comida corrida''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || small menu at fixed price |- || '''el tamarindo''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the tamarind |- || '''hasta luego''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || see you later |- |}
{{SbcMoreVocabularySpanishPod}} {| |- |align="right"| '''tener''' || {{SbcInf}} || to have |- |align="right"| '''(yo) tengo''' || {{SbcPT}} || I have |- |align="right"| '''(tú) tienes''' || || you have (informal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(él/ella) tiene''' || || he/she(/it) has |- |align="right"| '''(usted) tiene''' || || you have (formal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(nosotros/-as) tenemos'''|| || we have (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(vosotros/-as) tenéis'''|| || you have (informal, plural, m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ellos/ellas) tienen'''|| || they have (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ustedes) tienen''' || || you have (formal, plural) |- ||   || |- |align="right"| '''ir''' || {{SbcInf}} || to go |- |align="right"| '''(yo) voy''' || {{SbcPT}} || I go |- |align="right"| '''(tú) vas''' || || you go (informal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(él/ella) va''' || || he/she(/it) goes |- |align="right"| '''(usted) va'''|| || you go (formal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(nosotros/-as) vamos''' || || we go (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(vosotros/-as) vais''' || || you go (informal, plural, m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ellos/ellas) van''' || || they go (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ustedes) van''' || || you go (formal, plural) |- ||   || |- |align="right"| '''querer''' || {{SbcInf}} || to want |- |align="right"| '''(yo) quiero''' || {{SbcPT}} || I want |- |align="right"| '''(tú) quieres''' || || you want (informal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(él/ella) quiere''' || || he/she(/it) wants |- |align="right"| '''(usted) quiere''' || || you want (formal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(nosotros/-as) queremos'''|| || we want (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(vosotros/-as) queréis'''|| || you want (informal, plural, m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ellos/ellas) quieren'''|| || they want (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ustedes) quieren''' || || you want (formal, plural) |- |}
{{SbcExercisesSpanishPod}} <noinclude>====Dialogue Translation==== Translate from Spanish to English. Click each bar to check your answer. If possible, read the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestion | '''Tengo hambre.''' | I'm hungry. | '''Yo también. ¿Vamos a comer?''' | Me too. Are we going to eat? | '''Sí, quiero ir a un restaurante italiano.''' | Yes, I want to go to a Italian restaurant. | '''Buena idea.''' | Good idea. }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Translation==== Cover the right column, translate from Spanish to English and uncover the right column line by line to check your answers. If possible, read the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestionPrint | '''Tengo hambre.''' | I'm hungry. | '''Yo también. ¿Vamos a comer?''' | Me too. Are we going to eat? | '''Sí, quiero ir a un restaurante italiano.''' | Yes, I want to go to a Italian restaurant. | '''Buena idea.''' | Good idea. }}</includeonly> <noinclude>====Dialogue Recall==== Now translate from English to Spanish. Remember to say the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestion | I'm hungry. | '''Tengo hambre.''' | Me too. Are we going to eat? | '''Yo también. ¿Vamos a comer?''' | Yes, I want to go to an Italian restaurant. | '''Sí, quiero ir a un restaurante italiano.''' | Good idea. | '''Buena idea.''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Recall==== Now translate from English to Spanish. Remember to say the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestionPrint | I'm hungry. | '''Tengo hambre.''' | Me too. Are we going to eat? | '''Yo también. ¿Vamos a comer?''' | Yes, I want to go to an Italian restaurant. | '''Sí, quiero ir a un restaurante italiano.''' | Good idea. | '''Buena idea.''' }}</includeonly> <noinclude>====Dialogue Remix==== Translate this variant of the dialogue from English to Spanish. {{SbcQuestion | I want to go to a restaurant | '''Quiero ir a un restaurante.''' | Good idea! I'm hungry, too. | '''¡Buena idea! Tengo hambre también.''' | Are we going to go to a French restaurant? | '''¿Vamos a ir a un restaurante francés?''' | I want to eat Spanish food. | '''Yo quiero comer comida española.''' | Good. Let's go to a Spanish restaurant. | '''Bueno. Vamos a un restaurante español.''' | Let's go! | '''¡Vamos!''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Remix==== Translate this variant of the dialogue from English to Spanish. {{SbcQuestionPrint | I want to go to a restaurant | '''Quiero ir a un restaurante.''' | Good idea! I'm hungry, too. | '''¡Buena idea! Tengo hambre también.''' | Are we going to go to a French restaurant? | '''¿Vamos a ir a un restaurante francés?''' | I want to eat Spanish food. | '''Yo quiero comer comida española.''' | Good. Let's go to a Spanish restaurant. | '''Bueno. Vamos a un restaurante español.''' | Let's go! | '''¡Vamos!''' }}</includeonly> <noinclude>====Dialogue Recast==== This translation exercise requires some of the words from the [[#More Vocabulary|More Vocabulary]] section. {{SbcQuestion | We are hungry. | '''Tenemos hambre.''' | We too. Are you going to eat? (informal, plural) | '''Nosotros también. ¿Vais a comer?''' | Yes, we want to go to an Italian restaurant. | '''Sí, queremos ir a un restaurante italiano.''' | Good idea. | '''Buena idea.''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Recast==== This translation exercise requires some of the words from the More Vocabulary section. {{SbcQuestionPrint | We are hungry. | '''Tenemos hambre.''' | We too. Are you going to eat? (informal, plural) | '''Nosotros también. ¿Vais a comer?''' | Yes, we want to go to an Italian restaurant. | '''Sí, queremos ir a un restaurante italiano.''' | Good idea. | '''Buena idea.''' }}</includeonly>

page.title: Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0013

revision.text:
<noinclude>{{SbcHeaderSpanishPod|title=Doing the Laundry|id=A0013}}</noinclude> {{SbcIntroductionSpanishPod}} Searching for something can be quite frustrating; thus, it's usually better to ask. Liliana and JP teach us how. Moreover, we learn about an easy way to express the future, how to say “there is” in Spanish, and more. The keywords are: '''no sé''' – I don't know; and '''¿dónde?''' – where? {{SbcSourceSpanishPod|[[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0001|A0001: Are you ready yet?]], [[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0035|A0035: Is anyone in there?]], [[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0037|A0037: The baby is sleeping]]}} <noinclude>{{SbcAudioSpanishPod|title=Doing the Laundry|id=A0013|dialogueid=A0013 dialogue}}</noinclude> {{SbcDialogueSpanishPod}} :{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''Voy a lavar la ropa. ¿Hay detergente?'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0013 line 1}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''Sí hay, abajo en la cocina.'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0013 line 2}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''¿Dónde? ¿En qué parte?'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0013 line 3}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''No sé. ¡Búscalo!'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0013 line 4}}</noinclude> |- |}
{{SbcDialogueWithTranslationSpanishPod}} :{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''Voy''' || '''a''' || '''lavar''' || '''la''' || '''ropa.''' || '''¿Hay''' || '''detergente?'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0013 line 1}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| ||''(I) go'' || ''to'' || ''wash'' || ''the'' || ''clothes'' || ''there is'' || ''detergent'' |- |align="right"|''man:'' ||colspan=7| I'm going to wash clothes. Is there detergent? |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''Sí''' || '''hay,''' || '''abajo''' || '''en''' || '''la''' || '''cocina.'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0013 line 2}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| || ''yes'' || ''there is'' || ''down'' || ''in'' || ''the'' || ''kitchen'' |- |align="right"|''woman:'' ||colspan=6| Yes, there is, downstairs in the kitchen. |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''¿Dónde?''' || '''¿En''' || '''qué''' || '''parte?'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0013 line 3}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| ||''where'' || ''in'' || ''what'' || ''part'' |- |align="right"|''man:'' ||colspan=4| Where? In what part? |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''No''' || '''sé.''' || '''¡Búscalo!'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0013 line 4}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| || ''no'' || ''(I) know'' || ''(you) search it'' |- |align="right"|''woman:'' ||colspan=3| I don't know. Look for it. |- |}
{{Wikipedia|Hay Amores}}{{Wikipedia|¿Dónde están los ladrones?}} [[Image:Santa Claus clothes.jpg|thumb|'''la ropa''' – the clothes|160px]] [[Image:2005-11 Bocholt Textilmuseum 04.JPG|thumb|'''la cocina''' – the kitchen|160px]] ===Vocabulary for Dialogue=== :{| |- || '''el hombre''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the man |- || '''la mujer''' || {{SbcNounF}} || the woman |- || '''ir''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to go |- || '''(yo) voy''' || {{SbcVerbPT}} || I go |- || '''a''' || {{SbcPreposition}} || to |- || '''lavar''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to wash |- || '''voy a lavar''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || I'm going to wash |- || '''la ropa''' || {{SbcNounF}} || the clothes |- || '''hay''' || {{SbcVerbPT}} || there is, there are |- || '''el detergente''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the detergent |- || '''sí''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || yes |- || '''abajo''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || down, below, downstairs |- || '''en''' || {{SbcPreposition}} || in |- || '''la cocina''' || {{SbcNounF}} || the kitchen |- || '''¿dónde?''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || where? |- || '''¿qué?''' || {{SbcInterrogativePronoun}} || what? |- || '''la parte''' || {{SbcNounF}} || the part |- || '''no''' || {{SbcAdverb}} || no |- || '''saber''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to know |- || '''(yo) sé''' || {{SbcVerbPT}} || I know |- || '''buscar''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to search |- || '''¡(tú) busca!''' || {{SbcVerbImp}} || (you) search! (informal, singular) |- || '''lo''' || {{SbcDirectPronoun}} || him, it |- || '''¡(tú) búscalo!''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || (you) look for it! (informal, singular) |- |}
{{Wikipedia|gasolina}}{{Wikipedia|guapa}}{{Wikipedia|teatro (album)}} ===Vocabulary for Audio Lesson=== :{| |- || '''la comida''' || {{SbcNounF}} || the food |- || '''la gasolina''' || {{SbcNounF}} || the gasoline |- || '''las mujeres''' || {{SbcNounPF}} || the women |- || '''guapo/guapa''' || {{SbcAdjectiveMF}} || beautiful |- || '''guapos/guapas''' || {{SbcAdjectivePMF}} || beautiful |- || '''la mujer guapa''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || the beautiful woman |- || '''las mujeres guapas''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || the beautiful women |- || '''comer''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to eat |- || '''voy a comer''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || I'm going to eat |- || '''bailar''' || {{SbcVerbInf}} || to dance |- || '''el cine''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the cinema |- || '''al''' (= '''a el''') || {{SbcPhrase}} || to the |- || '''voy al cine''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || I'm going to the movies |- || '''el teatro''' || {{SbcNounM}} || the theater |- || '''voy al teatro''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || I'm going to the theater |- || '''hasta luego''' || {{SbcPhrase}} || see you later |- |}
{{SbcMoreVocabularySpanishPod}} {| |- |align="right"| '''ir''' || {{SbcInf}} || to go |- |align="right"| '''(yo) voy''' || {{SbcPT}} || I go |- |align="right"| '''(tú) vas''' || || you go (informal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(él/ella) va''' || || he/she(/it) goes |- |align="right"| '''(usted) va'''|| || you go (formal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(nosotros/-as) vamos''' || || we go (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(vosotros/-as) vais''' || || you go (informal, plural, m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ellos/ellas) van''' || || they go (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ustedes) van''' || || you go (formal, plural) |- ||   || |- |align="right"| '''saber''' || {{SbcInf}} || to know |- |align="right"| '''(yo) sé''' || {{SbcPT}} || I know |- |align="right"| '''(tú) sabes''' || || you know (informal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(él/ella) sabe''' || || he/she(/it) knows |- |align="right"| '''(usted) sabe''' || || you know (formal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''(nosotros/-as) sabemos'''|| || we know (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(vosotros/-as) sabéis'''|| || you know (informal, plural, m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ellos/ellas) saben'''|| || they know (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''(ustedes) saben''' || || you know (formal, plural) |- ||   || |- |align="right"| '''buscar'''|| {{SbcInf}} || to search |- |align="right"| '''¡(tú) busca!'''|| {{SbcImp}} || (you) search! (informal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''¡(usted) busque!''' || || (you) search! (formal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''¡(nosotros/-as) busquemos!''' || || (let's) search! (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''¡(vosotros/-as) buscad!''' || || (you) search! (informal, plural, m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''¡(ustedes) busquen!'''|| || (you) search! (formal, plural) |- ||   || |- |align="right"| '''me'''|| {{SbcDirectPronoun}} || me |- |align="right"| '''te'''|| || you (informal, singular) |- |align="right"| '''lo/la'''|| || him/her(/it) |- |align="right"| '''lo/la'''|| || you (formal, singular, m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''nos'''|| || us |- |align="right"| '''os'''|| || you (informal, plural) |- |align="right"| '''los/las'''|| || them (m./f.) |- |align="right"| '''los/las'''|| || you (formal, plural, m./f.) |- |}
{{SbcExercisesSpanishPod}} <noinclude>====Dialogue Translation==== Translate from Spanish to English. Click each bar to check your answer. If possible, read the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestion | '''Voy a lavar la ropa. ¿Hay detergente?''' | I'm going to wash clothes. Is there detergent? | '''Sí hay, abajo en la cocina.''' | Yes, there is, downstairs in the kitchen. | '''¿Dónde? ¿En qué parte?''' | Where? In what part? | '''No sé. ¡Búscalo!''' | I don't know. Look for it. }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Translation==== Cover the right column, translate from Spanish to English and uncover the right column line by line to check your answers. If possible, read the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestionPrint | '''Voy a lavar la ropa. ¿Hay detergente?''' | I'm going to wash clothes. Is there detergent? | '''Sí hay, abajo en la cocina.''' | Yes, there is, downstairs in the kitchen. | '''¿Dónde? ¿En qué parte?''' | Where? In what part? | '''No sé. ¡Búscalo!''' | I don't know. Look for it. }}</includeonly> <noinclude>====Dialogue Recall==== Now translate from English to Spanish. Remember to say the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestion | I'm going to wash clothes. Is there detergent?| '''Voy a lavar la ropa. ¿Hay detergente?''' | Yes, there is, downstairs in the kitchen.| '''Sí hay, abajo en la cocina.''' | Where? In what part?| '''¿Dónde? ¿En qué parte?''' | I don't know. Look for it.| '''No sé. ¡Búscalo!''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Recall==== Now translate from English to Spanish. Remember to say the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestionPrint | I'm going to wash clothes. Is there detergent?| '''Voy a lavar la ropa. ¿Hay detergente?''' | Yes, there is, downstairs in the kitchen.| '''Sí hay, abajo en la cocina.''' | Where? In what part?| '''¿Dónde? ¿En qué parte?''' | I don't know. Look for it.| '''No sé. ¡Búscalo!''' }}</includeonly> <noinclude>====Dialogue Remix==== Translate this variant of the dialogue from English to Spanish. {{SbcQuestion | I'm going to wash the clothes in the kitchen. | '''Voy a lavar la ropa en la cocina.''' | There is no detergent. | '''No hay detergente.''' | I'm going to look for it. | '''Voy a buscarlo.''' | What? | '''¿Qué?''' | The detergent. | '''El detergente.''' | There is no detergent! | '''¡No hay detergente!''' | Yes, I'm going to look for it. | '''Sí, voy a buscarlo.''' | Where? | '''¿Dónde?''' | Downstairs in the kitchen. | '''Abajo en la cocina.''' | ¿In what part? | '''¿En qué parte?''' | I don't know. | '''No sé.''' | Look for it. | '''¡Búscalo!''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Remix==== Translate this variant of the dialogue from English to Spanish. {{SbcQuestionPrint | I'm going to wash the clothes in the kitchen. | '''Voy a lavar la ropa en la cocina.''' | There is no detergent. | '''No hay detergente.''' | I'm going to look for it. | '''Voy a buscarlo.''' | What? | '''¿Qué?''' | The detergent. | '''El detergente.''' | There is no detergent! | '''¡No hay detergente!''' | Yes, I'm going to look for it. | '''Sí, voy a buscarlo.''' | Where? | '''¿Dónde?''' | Downstairs in the kitchen. | '''Abajo en la cocina.''' | In what part? | '''¿En qué parte?''' | I don't know. | '''No sé.''' | Look for it. | '''¡Búscalo!''' }}</includeonly> <noinclude>====Dialogue Recast==== This translation exercise requires some of the words from the [[#More Vocabulary|More Vocabulary]] section. {{SbcQuestion | We're going to wash clothes. Is there detergent?| '''Vamos a lavar la ropa. ¿Hay detergente?''' | Yes, there is, downstairs in the kitchen.| '''Sí hay, abajo en la cocina.''' | Where? In what part?| '''¿Dónde? ¿En qué parte?''' | You don't know (informal). Let us look for it!| '''No sabes. ¡Busquémoslo!''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Recast==== This translation exercise requires some of the words from the More Vocabulary section. {{SbcQuestionPrint | We're going to wash clothes. Is there detergent?| '''Vamos a lavar la ropa. ¿Hay detergente?''' | Yes, there is, downstairs in the kitchen.| '''Sí hay, abajo en la cocina.''' | Where? In what part?| '''¿Dónde? ¿En qué parte?''' | You don't know (informal). Let us look for it!| '''No sabes. ¡Busquémoslo!''' }}</includeonly>

revision.text:
<noinclude>{{SbcHeaderSpanishPod|title=Table for Two|id=A0015}}</noinclude> {{SbcIntroductionSpanishPod}} Let's be polite!—Does it matter? Well, yes. At least you should know the difference. JP and Liliana talk us through it by discussing how to be seated in a restaurant. The keyword is: '''reservación''' – reservation. {{SbcSourceSpanishPod|[[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0010|A0010: I'm hungry]], [[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0041|A0041: Cheers!]], [[Spanish by Choice/SpanishPod newbie lesson A0062|A0062: At the bank]]}} <noinclude>{{SbcAudioSpanishPod|title=Table for Two|id=A0015|dialogueid=A0015 dialogue}}</noinclude> {{SbcDialogueSpanishPod}} :{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''Mesa para dos, si es tan amable.'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0015 line 1}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''¿Tiene reservación?'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0015 line 2}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''No, no tengo.'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0015 line 3}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''No importa. Síganme por favor.'''<noinclude>||align="right"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0015 line 4}}</noinclude> |- |}
{{SbcDialogueWithTranslationSpanishPod}} :{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''Mesa''' || '''para''' || '''dos,''' || '''si''' || '''es''' || '''tan''' || '''amable.'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0015 line 1}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| ||''table'' || ''for'' || ''two'' || ''if'' || ''(you) are'' || ''so'' || ''kind'' |- |align="right"|''man:'' ||colspan=7| Table for two, if you'd be so kind. |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''mujer:'' || '''¿Tiene''' || '''reservación?'''<noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0015 line 2}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| || ''(you) have'' || ''reservation'' |- |align="right"|''woman:'' ||colspan=3| Do you have a reservation? |- |}
:{| |- |align="right"|''hombre:'' || '''No,''' || '''no''' || '''tengo.''' <noinclude>||align="right" valign="top" rowspan="3"|{{SbcAudioSpanishPodLine|id=A0015 line 3}}</noinclude> |- |align="right"| ||''no'' || ''not'' || ''(I) have'' |- |align="right"|''man:'' ||colspan=3| No, I don't. |- |}

Follow me please. |- |}

{{SbcExercisesSpanishPod}} <noinclude>====Dialogue Translation==== Translate from Spanish to English. Click each bar to check your answer. If possible, read the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestion | '''Mesa para dos, si es tan amable.''' | Table for two, if you'd be so kind. | '''¿Tiene reservación?''' | Do you have a reservation? | '''No, no tengo.''' | No, I don't. | '''No importa. Síganme por favor.''' | It doesn't matter. Follow me please. }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Translation==== Cover the right column, translate from Spanish to English and uncover the right column line by line to check your answers. If possible, read the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestionPrint | '''Mesa para dos, si es tan amable.''' | Table for two, if you'd be so kind. | '''¿Tiene reservación?''' | Do you have a reservation? | '''No, no tengo.''' | No, I don't. | '''No importa. Síganme por favor.''' | It doesn't matter. Follow me please. }}</includeonly> <noinclude>====Dialogue Recall==== Now translate from English to Spanish. Remember to say the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestion | Table for two, if you are so kind. | '''Mesa para dos, si es tan amable.''' | Do you have a reservation? | '''¿Tiene reservación?''' | No, I don't. | '''No, no tengo.''' | It doesn't matter. Follow me please. | '''No importa. Síganme por favor.''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Recall==== Now translate from English to Spanish. Remember to say the Spanish sentences aloud. {{SbcQuestionPrint | Table for two, if you are so kind. | '''Mesa para dos, si es tan amable.''' | Do you have a reservation? | '''¿Tiene reservación?''' | No, I don't. | '''No, no tengo.''' | It doesn't matter. Follow me please. | '''No importa. Síganme por favor.''' }}</includeonly> <noinclude>====Dialogue Remix==== Translate this variant of the dialogue from English to Spanish. {{SbcQuestion | A table for two, please. I don't have a reservation. | '''Mesa para dos, por favor. No tengo reservación.''' | You don't have a reservation? | '''¿No tiene reservación?''' | No, I don't have. Does it matter? | '''No, no tengo. ¿Importa?''' | No, it doesn't matter. | '''No, no importa.''' | You are kind. | '''Es amable.''' | For two? Follow me, please. | '''¿Para dos? Síganme, por favor.''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Remix==== Translate this variant of the dialogue from English to Spanish. {{SbcQuestionPrint | A table for two, please. I don't have a reservation. | '''Mesa para dos, por favor. No tengo reservación.''' | You don't have a reservation? | '''¿No tiene reservación?''' | No, I don't have. Does it matter? | '''No, no tengo. ¿Importa?''' | No, it doesn't matter. | '''No, no importa.''' | You are kind. | '''Es amable.''' | For two? Follow me, please. | '''¿Para dos? Síganme, por favor.''' }}</includeonly> <noinclude>====Dialogue Recast==== This translation exercise requires some of the words from the [[#More Vocabulary|More Vocabulary]] section. {{SbcQuestion | Table for two, if you are so kind. (informal) | '''Mesa para dos, si eres tan amable.''' | Do you have a reservation? (informal) | '''¿Tienes reservación?''' | No, we don't. | '''No, no tenemos.''' | It doesn't matter. Follow me please. (informal, plural) | '''No importa. Seguidme por favor.''' }}</noinclude><includeonly>====Dialogue Recast==== This translation exercise requires some of the words from the More Vocabulary section. {{SbcQuestionPrint | Table for two, if you are so kind. (informal) | '''Mesa para dos, si eres tan amable.''' | Do you have a reservation? (informal) | '''¿Tienes reservación?''' | No, we don't. | '''No, no tenemos.''' | It doesn't matter. Follow me please. (informal, plural) | '''No importa. Seguidme por favor.''' }}</includeonly>

revision.comment: New page: Rajan paudel(king_paudel@yahoo.com) Energy Crisis: can we make difference? Soaring world population, adoption of energy intensive lifestyle (in developing countries like China, India etc.)...
revision.text: Rajan paudel(king_paudel@yahoo.com) Energy Crisis: can we make difference? Soaring world population, adoption of energy intensive lifestyle (in developing countries like China, India etc.), increased no of automobiles, aircrafts and industries has increased the demand for energy. 85% of the world's energy supply in 2008 is supplied by Coal and natural gas alone (planetforlife.com) .Since fuel energy is the main resource used to exploit all other resources, its decline will result bottleneck in the supply of energy resources which ultimately leads to energy crisis. If this trend of unabated energy consumption continues it will get exhausted completely in less than 42 years. It is of utmost importance that the public and especially policymakers understand the global energy crisis. If we do nothing, our children will inherit a disabled country where they would starve for nothing but death. It‘s high time for us to innovate new technologies, think globally and act locally. Opting for the alternative source of energy like wind power, solar power, geothermal energy, hydropower nuclear power etc. is the only solution seen till date. Nuclear fusion and fission can be other sources which are mind-numbing for countries like Nepal. Effective, economic and efficient measures must be adopted to prolong the availability of fuel energy. Use of florescent lamps in place of bulbs can save 60% energy. Cover the water heater by insulation blanket; it saves 1000 pound CO2 per year. Use of pressure cooker saves 70% energy as well as cuts cooking time considerably. Cover the pots by lid while cooking, by doing this the stem generated inside the container helps cook food faster along with preservation of energy. Do not directly heat the cooking items soon after they are taken out of refrigerator. Extra energy of gas is required by burner to bring it in the room temperature. Gas stove should be turned on only when fire producing objects like matchbox, lighter or electronic sparking device are near and handy (dali, 2008). Unnecessarily big utensils should be avoided as they consume more fuel without any attendant benefit. Use washing machine when it is full; apply proper economic settings if it is half filled. Recycle the wastages of home; it can save 2400 pounds of CO2 per year. Preserve greenery, plants absorbs the CO2 and minimizes the flow of sound. Consume locally available food materials. Fuel is consumed while transporting goods from one place to other. Walk more, ride less as far as possible. Drive safe and economic, use engine break instead of pedal brakes. Turn off the engines if the vehicle has to stop for more than 2 minutes. You can make a difference if you follow above recommendations. Opting for the alternative source of energy (like wind power, solar power, geothermal energy, hydropower nuclear power etc.) is the best solution. It also leads to lower emission of CO2 (Dali, 2008), a gas responsible for green house effect and global warming. Converting the nature endowed ‘white gold’ flowing in the rivers which has the capacity of producing more than 80000MW electricity is the better choice for Nepal. But merely 4% (around615MW) has been produced till date(Chand2003). Emerging concept of clean development mechanism (C.D.M), and payment for environmental services (PES) has been developed which assist in resolving the problem.

Mechanics 2 is an applied maths module for the edexcel exam board for A-Levels.

It comprises the following modules:

how all frequency carriers of signals get carried through a coaxial cable?
:Magic! The answer is frequency division multiplexing (FDM) where each carrier is a different frequency, and all the frequencies are added together into the spectrum. At the receiving end, a series of filters can separate each carrier out from the spectrum, frequency shift it back to DC, and reconstructs it into the transmitted signal. --'''Whiteknight''' ([[User:Whiteknight|Page]]) ([[User talk:Whiteknight|Talk]]) 20:27, 19 September 2008 (UTC)

revision.comment: moved [[Internet Technologies/Wireless Connnectivity]] to [[Internet Technologies/Wireless connectivity]]: spelling error in "Connnectivity"
revision.text:
Wireless is a generic term that refers to the transfer of data between sendeer and receiver via radio (or optical) waves of different frequencies. Wireless is a group of related technologies that are different from each other in their speed, range, power, and compatibility. Two of the most popular technologies include Wi-Fi, Bluetooth.
Wi-Fi is the most popular form of wirless connection. It belongs to the 802.11 protocol family. Wi-Fi is a radio-based wireless internet that is high powered. It can handle large amounts of data of long distances.
Bluetooth is a low-powered alternative that transmits data slowly over short distances. It uses a very secure digital radio communication that is not tied to any particular radio frequency. The name Bluetooth comes from a tenth-century Viking king who unified Norway and Denmark.
Source: Siegel, Carolyn. Internet Marketing Fundation and Applications. 2. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company, 2006.
[[category:Internet Technologies|Wireless Connectivity]]

revision.comment: Undid revision 2287975: Comment either needs to be a definite statement with more detail, or should be a discussion on the talk page.
revision.text:
== Enumerable == Enumerator appears in Ruby as Enumerable::Enumerator in 1.8.x and (just) Enumerator in 1.9.x. = Forms of Enumerator = There are several different ways in which an Enumerator can be used:
* As a proxy for “each”
* As a source of values from a block
* As an external iterator == 1. As a proxy for “each” == This is the first way of using Enumerator, introduced in ruby 1.8. It solves the following problem: Enumerable methods like #map and #select call #each on your object, but what if you want to iterate using some other method such as #each_byte or #each_with_index? An Enumerator is a simple proxy object which takes a call to #each and redirects it to a different method on the underlying object. 
require 'enumerator'   # needed in ruby <= 1.8.6 only

src = "hello"
puts src.enum_for(:each_byte).map { |b| "%02x" % b }.join(" ")
The call to ‘enum_for’ (or equivalently ‘to_enum’) creates the Enumerator proxy. It is a shorthand for the following: 
newsrc = Enumerable::Enumerator.new(src, :each_byte)
puts newsrc.map { |b| "%02x" % b }.join(" ")
In ruby 1.9, Enumerable::Enumerator has changed to just Enumerator == 2. As a source of values from a block == In ruby 1.9, Enumerator.new can instead take a block which is executed when #each is called, and directly yields the values. 
block =  Enumerator.new {|g| g.yield 1; g.yield 2; g.yield 3}

block.each do |item|
  puts item
end
“g << 1” is an alternative syntax for “g.yield 1” No fancy language features such as Fiber or Continuation are used, and this form of Enumerator is easily [http://github.com/trans/facets/blob/master/lib/more/facets/enumerator.rb retro-fitted to ruby 1.8] It is quite similar to creating your own object which yields values: 
block = Object.new
def block.each
  yield 1; yield 2; yield 3
end

block.each do |item|
  puts item
end
However it also lays the groundwork for “lazy” evaluation of enumerables, described later. == 3. As an external iterator == ruby 1.9 also allows you turn an Enumerator around so that it becomes a “pull” source of values, sometimes known as “external iteration”. Look carefully at the difference between this and the previous example: 
block =  Enumerator.new {|g| g.yield 1; g.yield 2; g.yield 3}

while item = block.next
  puts item
end
The flow of control switches back and forth, and the first time you call #next a Fiber is created which holds the state between calls. Therefore it is less efficient that iterating directly using #each. When you call #next and there are no more values, a StopIteration exception is thrown. This is silently caught by the while loop. StopIteration is a subclass of IndexError which is a subclass of StandardError. The nearest equivalent feature in ruby 1.8 is Generator, which was implemented using Continuations. 
require 'generator'
block = Generator.new {|g| g.yield 1; g.yield 2; g.yield 3}

while block.next?
  puts block.next
end
= Lazy evaluation = In an Enumerator with a block, the target being yielded to is passed as an explicit parameter. This makes it possible to set up a chain of method calls so that each value is passed left-to-right along the whole chain, rather than building up intermediate arrays of values at each step. The basic pattern is an Enumerator with a block which processes input values and yields (zero or more) output values for each one. 
  Enumerator.new do |y|
    source.each do |input|     # filter INPUT
      ...
      y.yield output           # filter OUTPUT
    end
  end
So let’s wrap this in a convenience method: 
class Enumerator
  def defer(&blk)
    self.class.new do |y|
      each do |*input|
        blk.call(y, *input)
      end
    end
  end
end
This new method ‘defer’ can be used as a ‘lazy’ form of both select and map. Rather than building an array of values and returning that array at the end, it immediately yields each value. This means you start getting the answers sooner, and it will work with huge or even infinite lists. Example: 
res = (1..1_000_000_000).to_enum.
  defer { |out,inp| out.yield inp if inp % 2 == 0 }.   # like select
  defer { |out,inp| out.yield inp+100 }.               # like map
  take(10)
p res
Although we start with a list of a billion items, at the end we only use the first 10 values generated, so we stop iterating once this has been done. You can get the [http://github.com/trans/facets/blob/master/lib/core/facets/enumerable/defer.rb same capability] in ruby 1.8 using the [http://facets.rubyforge.org/ facets library.] For convenience it also provides a [http://github.com/trans/facets/blob/master/lib/core/facets/denumerable.rb Denumberable] module with lazy versions of familiar Enumerable methods such as map, select and reject. = Methods which return Enumerators = From 1.8.7 on, many Enumerable methods will return an Enumerator if not given a block. 
>> a = ["foo","bar","baz"]
=> ["foo", "bar", "baz"]
>> b = a.each_with_index
=> #<Enumerable::Enumerator:0xb7d7cadc>
>> b.each { |args| p args }
["foo", 0]
["bar", 1]
["baz", 2]
=> ["foo", "bar", "baz"]
>>
This means that usually you don’t need to call enum_for explicitly. The very first example on this page reduces to just: 
src = "hello"
puts src.each_byte.map { |b| "%02x" % b }.join(" ")
This can lead to somewhat odd behaviour for non-map like methods - when you call #each on the object later, you have to provide it with the “right sort” of block. 
=> ["foo", "bar", "baz"]
>> b = a.select
=> #<Enumerable::Enumerator:0xb7d6cfb0>
>> b.each { |arg| arg < "c" }
=> ["bar", "baz"]
>>
= More Enumerator readings = * [http://redmine.ruby-lang.org/issues/show/707 ticket 707] * [http://www.strictlyuntyped.com/2008/09/ruby-187s-enumerator-class.html enum_for] in Strictly Untyped blog * [http://anthonylewis.com/2007/11/09/ruby-generators/ Generator] in Anthony Lewis’ blog === each_with_index === each_with_index calls its block with the item and its index. array = ['Superman','Batman','The Hulk'] array.each_with_index do |item,index| puts "#{index} -> #{item}" end # will print # 0 -> Superman # 1 -> Batman # 2 -> The Hulk === find_all === find_all returns only those items for which the called block is not false range = 1 .. 10 # find the even numbers array = range.find_all { |item| item % 2 == 0 } # returns [2,4,6,8,10] array = ['Superman','Batman','Catwoman','Wonder Woman'] array = array.find_all { |item| item =~ /woman/ } # returns ['Catwoman','Wonder Woman'] {{BookCat}}

{{documentation}}

Over time, e-mail has been one of the most used components to send messages around the world or to people around oneself. Also, e-mail has alot of harm that can happen while in the process. There are different types of components that may occur while sending an innocent message to others. Email threats can be divided into several distinct categories: Viruses, Worms and Trojan Horses, Phishing, and also Spam. According to "IT Security," Viruses, Worms and Trojan Horses are delivered as email attachments, destructive code can devastate a host system's data, turn computers into remote control slaves known as bootnets and cause recipients to lose serious money. Trojan horse keyloggers, for example, can surreptitiously record system activities, giving unauthorized external parties access to corporate bank accounts, internal business Web sites and other private resources. Phishing attacks utilize social engineering to steal consumers' personal and financial data. Spam Although not an overt threat like a virus-infected attachment, junk email can quickly overwhelm an inbox, making it difficult or even impossible for its owner to view legitimate messages. The spam problem has gotten so bad that it is commonplace for users to abandon email accounts that are overrun with spam rather than try to fight the problem. Spam is also the delivery medium of choice for both phishers and virus attackers. As we can see, emails might be one of the top used networks, but many consequences can come from the technology.
{{BookCat}}

'''Online shopping''' is just like going to the store and shopping around and looking for things you want except in form of the internet. Tim Berners-Lee started the World Wide Web in 1990. Shortly there after, online shopping started and has expanded exponentially ever since. It provides such a convenience for consumers to keep from having to leave the house or use gas to get to all the different stores, where online shopping you can get anything you want from as many different stores as you want all at one time. Online shopping mainly takes place from people using search engines and typing in exactly what they want. Then the search engine will bring up the most popular sites for the items you look for. Once you find what you are looking for online, most sites will let you put the item in a shopping cart just like a brick and mortar store, so you can keep searching around for anything else that you may need.
Shopping online makes life so much easier because you can just type in a debit card number, wire money, deliver money, electronic money, etc. and be done with it within seconds or minutes. It makes life easy, but you just have to be careful what sites you order from because of all the scams that go on everyday. It is so easy for hackers today to steal people's identity, so being smart is definitely a key when shopping online.
It makes it easy for companies to use online catalogs or stores to do business not only because people will use it but because there is so much more of a selection that they can put online and not even have in the actual store due to space constraints.
== Online Auctions ==
Online auctions have become increasing popular with the rise of online shopping. These auctions allow buyers and sellers to obtain and sell products and services quickly and efficiently. Auctions allow for individuals and businesses to extend their products and services to a much larger customer base.
In 1995, the current powerhouse, Ebay, was started from founder Pierre Omidyar's house. While bidding and searching through auctions is free, sellers are charged certain fees:
- A nonrefundable Insertion Fee is charged which can cost a seller anywhere from 30 cents up to $3.30, depending on the seller's starting bid on the item. - If a seller wishes to further promote their listings, the seller can highlight a listing for an additional fee. - A Final Sale fee is charged at the end of the seller's auction. This fee generally ranges from 1.25% to 5% of the final sale price.
At the end of the auction, both the seller and the buyer are notified by Ebay. The seller usually has a minimum price they will accept for the bid item. If the buyer's bid exceeds the seller's lowest price, the transaction is completed between the two parties or independently of eBay. The above rules apply to Ebay itself, but all auction-based websites charge fees for providing customers with a specific place for e-commerce.
Although Ebay is a widely recognized name in the Internet world, there are several other popular auctions sites such as Ubid.com, Bidz.com, Webidz.com. Popularity and use of auction sites has become more common, however, there are some downsides to these websites. Once an auction has ended, the binding contract of the auction is between the winning bidder and the seller only. Meaning the actual website has limited to no liability for a bad transaction. Auction sites do provide their customers with several options to retrieve money from a dishonest buyer or seller. If these options fail to achieve results, the buyer or seller is essentially on their own.
There are many benefits from online auctions. Individuals and businesses sell and purchase products that are sometimes hard-to-find and hard to sell. Usually, these products come at cheaper prices, and can be found right in the comfort of your own home.
== Works Cited ==
* http://www.cs.brandeis.edu/~magnus/ief248a/eBay/history.html
* http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EBay
{{BookCat}}
